text: THE CROCK OF GOLD

author: Stephens, James

text: By James Stephens
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

text: BOOK I. THE COMING OF PAN
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: IN the centre of the pine wood called Coilla Doraca there lived not long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ago two Philosophers. They were wiser than anything else in the world
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: except the Salmon who lies in the pool of Glyn Cagny into which the nuts
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of knowledge fall from the hazel bush on its bank. He, of course, is the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: most profound of living creatures, but the two Philosophers are next to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him in wisdom. Their faces looked as though they were made of parchment,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there was ink under their nails, and every difficulty that was submitted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to them, even by women, they were able to instantly resolve. The Grey
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Woman of Dun Gortin and the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath asked them the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: three questions which nobody had ever been able to answer, and they were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: able to answer them. That was how they obtained the enmity of these two
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: women which is more valuable than the friendship of angels. The Grey
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Woman and the Thin Woman were so incensed at being answered that they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: married the two Philosophers in order to be able to pinch them in bed,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but the skins of the Philosophers were so thick that they did not know
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they were being pinched. They repaid the fury of the women with such
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tender affection that these vicious creatures almost expired of chagrin,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and once, in a very ecstacy of exasperation, after having been kissed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by their husbands, they uttered the fourteen hundred maledictions which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: comprised their wisdom, and these were learned by the Philosophers who
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thus became even wiser than before.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In due process of time two children were born of these marriages. They
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were born on the same day and in the same hour, and they were only
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: different in this, that one of them was a boy and the other one was a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: girl. Nobody was able to tell how this had happened, and, for the first
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time in their lives, the Philosophers were forced to admire an event
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which they had been unable to prognosticate; but having proved by many
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: different methods that the children were really children, that what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: must be must be, that a fact cannot be controverted, and that what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: has happened once may happen twice, they described the occurrence
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: as extraordinary but not unnatural, and submitted peacefully to a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Providence even wiser than they were.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher who had the boy was very pleased because, he said, there
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were too many women in the world, and the Philosopher who had the girl
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was very pleased also because, he said, you cannot have too much of a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good thing: the Grey Woman and the Thin Woman, however, were not in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: least softened by maternity-they said that they had not bargained for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it, that the children were gotten under false presences, that they were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: respectable married women, and that, as a protest against their wrongs,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they would not cook any more food for the Philosophers. This was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pleasant news for their husbands, who disliked the women's cooking
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: very much, but they did not say so, for the women would certainly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have insisted on their rights to cook had they imagined their husbands
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: disliked the results: therefore, the Philosophers besought their wives
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: every day to cook one of their lovely dinners again, and this the women
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: always refused to do.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They all lived together in a small house in the very centre of a dark
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pine wood. Into this place the sun never shone because the shade was too
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: deep, and no wind ever came there either, because the boughs were too
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thick, so that it was the most solitary and quiet place in the world,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the Philosophers were able to hear each other thinking all day long,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or making speeches to each other, and these were the pleasantest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sounds they knew of. To them there were only two kinds of sounds
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anywhere--these were conversation and noise: they liked the first very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: much indeed, but they spoke of the second with stern disapproval, and,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: even when it was made by a bird, a breeze, or a shower of rain, they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grew angry and demanded that it should be abolished. Their wives seldom
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: spoke at all and yet they were never silent: they communicated with each
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: other by a kind of physical telegraphy which they had learned among the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Shee-they cracked their finger-joints quickly or slowly and so were able
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to communicate with each other over immense distances, for by dint of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: long practice they could make great explosive sounds which were nearly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: like thunder, and gentler sounds like the tapping of grey ashes on a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hearthstone. The Thin Woman hated her own child, but she loved the Grey
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Woman's baby, and the Grey Woman loved the Thin Woman's infant but could
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not abide her own. A compromise may put an end to the most perplexing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of situations, and, consequently, the two women swapped children, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: at once became the most tender and amiable mothers imaginable, and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: families were able to live together in a more perfect amity than could
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be found anywhere else.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children grew in grace and comeliness. At first the little boy was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: short and fat and the little girl was long and thin, then the little
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: girl became round and chubby while the little boy grew lanky and wiry.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: This was because the little girl used to sit very quiet and be good and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the little boy used not.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They lived for many years in the deep seclusion of the pine wood wherein
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a perpetual twilight reigned, and here they were wont to play their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: childish games, flitting among the shadowy trees like little quick
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shadows. At times their mothers, the Grey Woman and the Thin Woman,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: played with them, but this was seldom, and sometimes their fathers, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: two Philosophers, came out and looked at them through spectacles which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were very round and very glassy, and had immense circles of horn all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: round the edges. They had, however, other playmates with whom they could
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: romp all day long. There were hundreds of rabbits running about in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brushwood; they were full of fun and were very fond of playing with the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children. There were squirrels who joined cheerfully in their games, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: some goats, having one day strayed in from the big world, were made so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: welcome that they always came again whenever they got the chance. There
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were birds also, crows and blackbirds and willy-wagtails, who were well
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: acquainted with the youngsters, and visited them as frequently as their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: busy lives permitted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: At a short distance from their home there was a clearing in the wood
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: about ten feet square; through this clearing, as through a funnel, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sun for a few hours in the summer time blazed down. It was the boy who
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: first discovered the strange radiant shaft in the wood. One day he had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been sent out to collect pine cones for the fire. As these were gathered
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: daily the supply immediately near the house was scanty, therefore he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had, while searching for more, wandered further from his home than
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: usual. The first sight of the extraordinary blaze astonished him. He
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had never seen anything like it before, and the steady, unwinking glare
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: aroused his fear and curiosity equally. Curiosity will conquer fear
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: even more than bravery will; indeed, it has led many people into dangers
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which mere physical courage would shudder away from, for hunger and love
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and curiosity are the great impelling forces of life. When the little
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: boy found that the light did not move he drew closer to it, and at last,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: emboldened by curiosity, he stepped right into it and found that it was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not a thing at all. The instant that he stepped into the light he found
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it was hot, and this so frightened him that he jumped out of it again
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and ran behind a tree. Then he jumped into it for a moment and out of it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again, and for nearly half an hour he played a splendid game of tip and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tig with the sunlight. At last he grew quite bold and stood in it and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: found that it did not burn him at all, but he did not like to remain
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in it, fearing that he might be cooked. When he went home with the pine
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cones he said nothing to the Grey Woman of Dun Gortin or to the Thin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Woman of Inis Magrath or to the two Philosophers, but he told the little
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: girl all about it when they went to bed, and every day afterwards they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: used to go and play with the sunlight, and the rabbits and the squirrels
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would follow them there and join in their games with twice the interest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they had shown before.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER II
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: To the lonely house in the pine wood people sometimes came for advice
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on subjects too recondite for even those extremes of elucidation, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: parish priest and the tavern. These people were always well received,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and their perplexities were attended to instantly, for the Philosophers
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: liked being wise and they were not ashamed to put their learning to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the proof, nor were they, as so many wise people are, fearful lest they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: should become poor or less respected by giving away their knowledge.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: These were favourite maxims with them:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: You must be fit to give before you can be fit to receive.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Knowledge becomes lumber in a week, therefore, get rid of it.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The box must be emptied before it can be refilled.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Refilling is progress.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: A sword, a spade, and a thought should never be allowed to rust.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Grey Woman and the Thin Woman, however, held opinions quite contrary
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to these, and their maxims also were different:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: A secret is a weapon and a friend.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Man is God's secret, Power is man's secret, Sex is woman's secret.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: By having much you are fitted to have more.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: There is always room in the box.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The art of packing is the last lecture of wisdom.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The scalp of your enemy is progress.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Holding these opposed views it seemed likely that visitors seeking for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: advice from the Philosophers might be astonished and captured by their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wives; but the women were true to their own doctrines and refused to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: part with information to any persons saving only those of high rank,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: such as policemen, gombeen men, and district and county councillors;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but even to these they charged high prices for their information, and a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bonus on any gains which accrued through the following of their advices.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It is unnecessary to state that their following was small when compared
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with those who sought the assistance of their husbands, for scarcely a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: week passed but some person came through the pine wood with his brows in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a tangle of perplexity.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In these people the children were deeply interested. They used to go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: apart afterwards and talk about them, and would try to remember what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they looked like, how they talked, and their manner of walking or taking
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: snuff. After a time they became interested in the problems which these
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: people submitted to their parents and the replies or instructions
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wherewith the latter relieved them. Long training had made the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children able to sit perfectly quiet, so that when the talk came to the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: interesting part they were entirely forgotten, and ideas which might
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: otherwise have been spared their youth became the commonplaces of their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conversation.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When the children were ten years of age one of the Philosophers died. He
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: called the household together and announced that the time had come when
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he must bid them all good-bye, and that his intention was to die as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: quickly as might be. It was, he continued, an unfortunate thing that his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: health was at the moment more robust than it had been for a long time,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but that, of course, was no obstacle to his resolution, for death did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not depend upon ill-health but upon a multitude of other factors with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the details whereof he would not trouble them.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: His wife, the Grey Woman of Dun Gortin, applauded this resolution and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: added as an amendment that it was high time he did something, that the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: life he had been leading was an arid and unprofitable one, that he had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stolen her fourteen hundred maledictions for which he had no use and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: presented her with a child for which she had none, and that, all things
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: concerned, the sooner he did die and stop talking the sooner everybody
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: concerned would be made happy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The other Philosopher replied mildly as he lit his pipe: "Brother,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the greatest of all virtues is curiosity, and the end of all desire
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is wisdom; tell us, therefore, by what steps you have arrived at this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: commendable resolution."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: To this the Philosopher replied: "I have attained to all the wisdom
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which I am fitted to bear. In the space of one week no new truth has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: come to me. All that I have read lately I knew before; all that I have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thought has been but a recapitulation of old and wearisome ideas. There
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is no longer an horizon before my eves. Space has narrowed to the petty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: dimensions of my thumb. Time is the tick of a clock. Good and evil are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: two peas in the one pod. My wife's face is the same for ever. I want to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: play with the children, and yet I do not want to. Your conversation with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: me, brother, is like the droning of a bee in a dark cell. The pine trees
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: take root and grow and die.--It's all bosh. Good-bye."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: His friend replied:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Brother, these are weighty reflections, and I do clearly perceive that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the time has come for you to stop. I might observe, not in order to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: combat your views, but merely to continue an interesting conversation,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that there are still some knowledges which you have not assimilated--you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: do not yet know how to play the tambourine, nor how to be nice to your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wife, nor how to get up first in the morning and cook the breakfast.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Have you learned how to smoke strong tobacco as I do? or can you dance
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the moonlight with a woman of the Shee? To understand the theory
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which underlies all things is not sufficient. It has occurred to me,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brother, that wisdom may not be the end of everything. Goodness and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: kindliness are, perhaps, beyond wisdom. Is it not possible that the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ultimate end is gaiety and music and a dance of joy? Wisdom is the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: oldest of all things. Wisdom is all head and no heart. Behold, brother,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you are being crushed under the weight of your head. You are dying of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: old age while you are yet a child."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Brother," replied the other Philosopher, "your voice is like the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: droning of a bee in a dark cell. If in my latter days I am reduced to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: playing on the tambourine and running after a hag in the moonlight, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cooking your breakfast in the grey morning, then it is indeed time that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I should die. Good-bye, brother."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So saying, the Philosopher arose and removed all the furniture to the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sides of the room so that there was a clear space left in the centre.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He then took off his boots and his coat, and standing on his toes he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: commenced to gyrate with extraordinary rapidity. In a few moments his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: movements became steady and swift, and a sound came from him like the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: humming of a swift saw; this sound grew deeper and deeper, and at last
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: continuous, so that the room was filled with a thrilling noise. In a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: quarter of an hour the movement began to noticeably slacken. In another
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: three minutes it was quite slow. In two more minutes he grew visible
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again as a body, and then he wobbled to and fro, and at last dropped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in a heap on the floor. He was quite dead, and on his face was an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: expression of serene beatitude.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with you, brother," said the remaining Philosopher, and he lit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his pipe, focused his vision on the extreme tip of his nose, and began
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to meditate profoundly on the aphorism whether the good is the all or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the all is the good. In another moment he would have become oblivious of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the room, the company, and the corpse, but the Grey Woman of Dun Gortin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Ought I indeed?" said the Thin Woman. "I'd have you know that I'll go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to bed when I like and get up when I like without asking your or any one
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: else's permission."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is not true," said the Philosopher. "You get sleepy whether you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: like it or not, and you awaken again without your permission being
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: asked. Like many other customs such as singing, dancing, music, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: acting, sleep has crept into popular favour as part of a religious
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ceremonial. Nowhere can one go to sleep more easily than in a church."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you know," said the Thin Woman, "that a Leprecaun came here to-day?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not," said the Philosopher, "and notwithstanding the innumerable
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: centuries which have elapsed since that first sleeper (probably with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: extreme difficulty) sank into his religious trance, we can to-day sleep
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: through a religious ceremony with an ease which would have been a source
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of wealth and fame to that prehistoric worshipper and his acolytes."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Are you going to listen to what I am telling you about the Leprecaun?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: said the Thin Woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am not," said the Philosopher. "It has been suggested that we go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to sleep at night because it is then too dark to do anything else; but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: owls, who are a venerably sagacious folk, do not sleep in the night
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time. Bats, also, are a very clear-minded race; they sleep in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: broadest day, and they do it in a charming manner. They clutch the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: branch of a tree with their toes and hang head downwards--a position
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which I consider singularly happy, for the rush of blood to the head
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: consequent on this inverted position should engender a drowsiness and a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: certain imbecility of mind which must either sleep or explode."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Will you never be done talking?" shouted the Thin Woman passionately.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not," said the Philosopher. "In certain ways sleep is useful.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It is an excellent way of listening to an opera or seeing pictures on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a bioscope. As a medium for day-dreams I know of nothing that can equal
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it. As an accomplishment it is graceful, but as a means of spending a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: night it is intolerably ridiculous. If you were going to say anything,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my love, please say it now, but you should always remember to think
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: before you speak. A woman should be seen seldom but never heard.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Quietness is the beginning of virtue. To be silent is to be beautiful.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Stars do not make a noise. Children should always be in bed. These are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: serious truths, which cannot be controverted; therefore, silence is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fitting as regards them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Your stirabout is on the hob," said the Thin Woman. "You can get it for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: yourself. I would not move the breadth of my nail if you were dying of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hunger. I hope there's lumps in it. A Leprecaun from Gort na Cloca Mora
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was here to-day. They'll give it to you for robbing their pot of gold.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: You old thief, you! you lobeared, crock-kneed fat-eye!"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman whizzed suddenly from where she stood and leaped into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bed. From beneath the blanket she turned a vivid, furious eye on her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: husband. She was trying to give him rheumatism and toothache and lockjaw
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: all at once. If she had been satisfied to concentrate her attention on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: one only of these torments she might have succeeded in afflicting her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: husband according to her wish, but she was not able to do that.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Finality is death. Perfection is finality. Nothing is perfect. There
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: are lumps in it," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER V
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: WHEN the Leprecaun came through the pine wood on the following day he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: met two children at a little distance from the house. He raised his open
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: right hand above his head (this is both the fairy and the Gaelic form of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: salutation), and would have passed on but that a thought brought him
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to a halt. Sitting down before the two children he stared at them for a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: long time, and they stared back at him. At last he said to the boy:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What is your name, a vic vig O?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Seumas Beg, sir," the boy replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's a little name," said the Leprecaun.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's what my mother calls me, sir," returned the boy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What does your father call you," was the next question.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Seumas Roghan Maelduin O'Carbhail Mac an Droid."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's a big name," said the Leprecaun, and he turned to the little girl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What is your name, a cailin vig O?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Brigid Beg, sir."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And what does your father call you?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He never calls me at all, sir."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, Seumaseen and Breedeen, you are good little children, and I like
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you very much. Health be with you until I come to see you again."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: And then the Leprecaun went back the way he had come. As he went he made
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: little jumps and cracked his fingers, and sometimes he rubbed one leg
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: against the other.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That's a nice Leprecaun," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I like him too," said Brigid.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Listen," said Seumas, "let me be the Leprecaun, and you be the two
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children, and I will ask you our names."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So they did that.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The next day the Leprecaun came again. He sat down beside the children
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and, as before, he was silent for a little time.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Are you not going to ask us our names, sir?" said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: His sister smoothed out her dress shyly. "My name, sir, is Brigid Beg,"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Did you ever play Jackstones?" said the Leprecaun.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, sir," replied Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll teach you how to play Jackstones," said the Leprecaun, and he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: picked up some pine cones and taught the children that game.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Did you ever play Ball in the Decker?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, sir," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Did you ever play 'I can make a nail with my ree-roraddy-O, I can make
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a nail with my ree-ro-ray'?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, sir," replied Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's a nice game," said the Leprecaun, "and so is Capon-the-back, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Twenty-four yards on the Billy-goat's Tail, and Towns, and Relievo, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Leap-frog. I'll teach you all these games," said the Leprecaun, "and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I'll teach you how to play Knifey, and Hole-and-taw, and Horneys and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Robbers.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Leap-frog is the best one to start with, so I'll teach it to you at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: once. Let you bend down like this, Breedeen, and you bend down like that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a good distance away, Seumas. Now I jump over Breedeen's back, and then
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I run and jump over Seumaseen's back like this, and then I run ahead
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again and I bend down. Now, Breedeen, you jump over your brother, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: then you jump over me, and run a good bit on and bend down again. Now,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Seumas, it's your turn; you jump over me and then over your sister, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: then you run on and bend down again and I jump."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "This is a fine game, sir," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is, a vic vig,--keep in your head," said the Leprecaun. "That's a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good jump, you couldn't beat that jump, Seumas."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I can jump better than Brigid already," replied Seumas, "and I'll jump
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: as well as you do when I get more practice--keep in your head, sir."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Almost without noticing it they had passed through the edge of the wood,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and were playing into a rough field which was cumbered with big, grey
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rocks. It was the very last field in sight, and behind it the rough,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: heather-packed mountain sloped distantly away to the skyline. There was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a raggedy blackberry hedge all round the field, and there were long,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tough, haggard-looking plants growing in clumps here and there. Near
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a corner of this field there was a broad, low tree, and as they played
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they came near and nearer to it. The Leprecaun gave a back very close to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the tree. Seumas ran and jumped and slid down a hole at the side of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tree. Then Brigid ran and jumped and slid down the same hole.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Dear me!" said Brigid, and she flashed out of sight.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Leprecaun cracked his fingers and rubbed one leg against the other,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then he also dived into the hole and disappeared from view.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When the time at which the children usually went home had passed, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Thin Woman of Inis Magrath became a little anxious. She had never known
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them to be late for dinner before. There was one of the children whom
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she hated; it was her own child, but as she had forgotten which of them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was hers, and as she loved one of them, she was compelled to love both
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for fear of making a mistake and chastising the child for whom her heart
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: secretly yearned. Therefore, she was equally concerned about both of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Dinner time passed and supper time arrived, but the children did not.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Again and again the Thin Woman went out through the dark pine trees and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: called until she was so hoarse that she could not even hear herself when
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she roared. The evening wore on to the night, and while she waited for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Philosopher to come in she reviewed the situation. Her husband had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not come in, the children had not come in, the Leprecaun had not returned
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: as arranged.... A light flashed upon her. The Leprecaun had kidnapped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her children! She announced a vengeance against the Leprecauns which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would stagger humanity. While in the extreme centre of her ecstasy the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Philosopher came through the trees and entered the house.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman flew to him-"Husband," said she, "the Leprecauns of Gort
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: na Cloca Mora have kidnapped our children."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher gazed at her for a moment.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Kidnapping," said he, "has been for many centuries a favourite
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: occupation of fairies, gypsies, and the brigands of the East. The usual
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: procedure is to attach a person and hold it to ransom. If the ransom is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not paid an ear or a finger may be cut from the captive and despatched
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to those interested, with the statement that an arm or a leg will follow
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in a week unless suitable arrangements are entered into."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you understand," said the Thin Woman passionately, "that it is your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: own children who have been kidnapped?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not," said the Philosopher. "This course, however, is rarely
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: followed by the fairy people: they do not ordinarily steal for ransom,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but for love of thieving, or from some other obscure and possibly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: functional causes, and the victim is retained in their forts or duns
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: until by the effluxion of time they forget their origin and become
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peaceable citizens of the fairy state. Kidnapping is not by any means
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: confined to either humanity or the fairy people."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Monster," said the Thin Woman in a deep voice, "will you listen to me?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not," said the Philosopher. "Many of the insectivora also
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: practice this custom. Ants, for example, are a respectable race living
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in well-ordered communities. They have attained to a most complex and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: artificial civilization, and will frequently adventure far afield on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: colonising or other expeditions from whence they return with a rich
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: booty of aphides and other stock, who thenceforward become the servants
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and domestic creatures of the republic. As they neither kill nor eat
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their captives, this practice will be termed kidnapping. The same may
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be said of bees, a hardy and industrious race living in hexagonal cells
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which are very difficult to make. Sometimes, on lacking a queen of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their own, they have been observed to abduct one from a less powerful
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: neighbour, and use her for their own purposes without shame, mercy, or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: remorse."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Will you not understand?" screamed the Thin Woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not," said the Philosopher. "Semi-tropical apes have been
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rumoured to kidnap children, and are reported to use them very tenderly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: indeed, sharing their coconuts, yams, plantains, and other equatorial
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: provender with the largest generosity, and conveying their delicate
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: captives from tree to tree (often at great distances from each other and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from the ground) with the most guarded solicitude and benevolence."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am going to bed," said the Thin Woman, "your stirabout is on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hob."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Are there lumps in it, my dear?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I hope there are," replied the Thin Woman, and she leaped into bed.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: That night the Philosopher was afflicted with the most extraordinary
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: attack of rheumatism he had ever known, nor did he get any ease until
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the grey morning wearied his lady into a reluctant slumber.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER VI
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: THE Thin Woman of Inis Magrath slept very late that morning, but when
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she did awaken her impatience was so urgent that she could scarcely
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: delay to eat her breakfast. Immediately after she had eaten she put on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her bonnet and shawl and went through the pine wood in the direction of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Gort na Cloca Mora. In a short time she reached the rocky field, and,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: walking over to the tree in the southeast corner, she picked up a small
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stone and hammered loudly against the trunk of the tree. She hammered
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in a peculiar fashion, giving two knocks and then three knocks, and then
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: one knock. A voice came up from the hole.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Who is that, please?" said the voice.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Ban na Droid of Inis Magrath, and well you know it," was her reply.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am coming up, Noble Woman," said the voice, and in another moment the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Leprecaun leaped out of the hole.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Where are Seumas and Brigid Beg?" said the Thin Woman sternly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "How would I know where they are?" replied the Leprecaun. "Wouldn't they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be at home now?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If they were at home I wouldn't have come here looking for them," was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her reply. "It is my belief that you have them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Search me," said the Leprecaun, opening his waistcoat.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "They are down there in your little house," said the Thin Woman angrily,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "and the sooner you let them up the better it will be for yourself and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: your five brothers."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Noble Woman," said the Leprecaun, "you can go down yourself into our
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: little house and look. I can't say fairer than that."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I wouldn't fit down there," said she. "I'm too big."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You know the way for making yourself little," replied the Leprecaun.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "But I mightn't be able to make myself big again," said the Thin Woman,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "and then you and your dirty brothers would have it all your own way. If
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you don't let the children up," she continued, "I'll raise the Shee of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Croghan Conghaile against you. You know what happened to the Cluricauns
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of Oilean na Glas when they stole the Queen's baby--It will be a worse
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing than that for you. If the children are not back in my house before
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: moonrise this night, I'll go round to my people. Just tell that to your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: five ugly brothers. Health with you," she added, and strode away.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Health with yourself, Noble Woman," said the Leprecaun, and he stood on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: one leg until she was out of sight and then he slid down into the hole
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When the Thin Woman was going back through the pine wood she saw Meehawl
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: MacMurrachu travelling in the same direction and his brows were in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tangle of perplexity.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with you, Meehawl MacMurrachu," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God and Mary be with you, ma'am," he replied, "I am in great trouble
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this day."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why wouldn't you be?" said the Thin Woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I came up to have a talk with your husband about a particular thing."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If it's talk you want you have come to a good house, Meehawl."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

text: head."
title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

text: Meehawl MacMurrachu had good reason to be perplexed. He was the father
title: The Crock of Gold

text: of one child only, and she was the most beautiful girl in the whole
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: world. The pity of it was that no one at all knew she was beautiful, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of a mountain stream and saw her reflection looking up from the placid
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James
