title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would come upon her, for what is the use of looking nice if there is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nobody to see one's beauty? Beauty, also, is usefulness. The arts as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: well as the crafts, the graces equally with the utilities must stand up
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the marketplace and be judged by the gombeen men.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The only house near to her father's was that occupied by Bessie
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Hannigan. The other few houses were scattered widely with long, quiet
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: miles of hill and bog between them, so that she had hardly seen more
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: than a couple of men beside her father since she was born. She helped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her father and mother in all the small businesses of their house, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: every day also she drove their three cows and two goats to pasture on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the mountain slopes. Here through the sunny days the years had passed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in a slow, warm thoughtlessness wherein, without thinking, many thoughts
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had entered into her mind and many pictures hung for a moment like
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: birds in the thin air. At first, and for a long time, she had been happy
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: enough; there were many things in which a child might be interested:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the spacious heavens which never wore the same beauty on any day; the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: innumerable little creatures living among the grasses or in the heather;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the steep swing of a bird down from the mountain to the infinite plains
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: below; the little flowers which were so contented each in its peaceful
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: place; the bees gathering food for their houses, and the stout beetles
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: who are always losing their way in the dusk. These things, and many
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: others, interested her. The three cows after they had grazed for a long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time would come and lie by her side and look at her as they chewed their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cud, and the goats would prance from the bracken to push their heads
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: against her breast because they loved her.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Indeed, everything in her quiet world loved this girl: but very slowly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there was growing in her consciousness an unrest, a disquietude to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which she had hitherto been a stranger. Sometimes an infinite weariness
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: oppressed her to the earth. A thought was born in her mind and it had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: no name. It was growing and could not be expressed. She had no words
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wherewith to meet it, to exorcise or greet this stranger who, more and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: more insistently and pleadingly, tapped upon her doors and begged to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be spoken to, admitted and caressed and nourished. A thought is a real
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing and words are only its raiment, but a thought is as shy as a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: virgin; unless it is fittingly apparelled we may not look on its shadowy
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nakedness: it will fly from us and only return again in the darkness
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: crying in a thin, childish voice which we may not comprehend until, with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: aching minds, listening and divining, we at last fashion for it those
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: symbols which are its protection and its banner. So she could not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: understand the touch that came to her from afar and yet how intimately,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the whisper so aloof and yet so thrillingly personal. The standard of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: either language or experience was not hers; she could listen but not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: think, she could feel but not know, her eyes looked forward and did not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: see, her hands groped in the sunlight and felt nothing. It was like the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: edge of a little wind which stirred her tresses but could not lift them,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or the first white peep of the dawn which is neither light nor darkness.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But she listened, not with her ears but with her blood. The fingers of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her soul stretched out to clasp a stranger's hand, and her disquietude
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was quickened through with an eagerness which was neither physical nor
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mental, for neither her body nor her mind was definitely interested.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Some dim region between these grew alarmed and watched and waited and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: did not sleep or grow weary at all.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: One morning she lay among the long, warm grasses. She watched a bird who
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: soared and sang for a little time, and then it sped swiftly away down
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the steep air and out of sight in the blue distance. Even when it was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gone the song seemed to ring in her ears. It seemed to linger with her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: as a faint, sweet echo, coming fitfully, with little pauses as though a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wind disturbed it, and careless, distant eddies. After a few moments she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: knew it was not a bird. No bird's song had that consecutive melody, for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their themes are as careless as their wings. She sat up and looked about
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her, but there was nothing in sight: the mountains sloped gently above
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her and away to the clear sky; around her the scattered clumps of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: heather were drowsing in the sunlight; far below she could see her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: father's house, a little grey patch near some trees-and then the music
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stopped and left her wondering.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: She could not find her goats anywhere although for a long time she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: searched. They came to her at last of their own accord from behind a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fold in the hills, and they were more wildly excited than she had ever
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: seen them before. Even the cows forsook their solemnity and broke into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: awkward gambols around her. As she walked home that evening a strange
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: elation taught her feet to dance. Hither and thither she flitted in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: front of the beasts and behind them. Her feet tripped to a wayward
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: measure. There was a tune in her ears and she danced to it, throwing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her arms out and above her head and swaying and bending as she went.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The full freedom of her body was hers now: the lightness and poise and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: certainty of her limbs delighted her, and the strength that did not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tire delighted her also. The evening was full of peace and quietude, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mellow, dusky sunlight made a path for her feet, and everywhere through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the wide fields birds were flashing and singing, and she sang with them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a song that had no words and wanted none.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The following day she heard the music again, faint and thin, wonderfully
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sweet and as wild as the song of a bird, but it was a melody which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: no bird would adhere to. A theme was repeated again and again. In the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: middle of trills, grace-notes, runs and catches it recurred with a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: strange, almost holy, solemnity,--a hushing, slender melody full of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: austerity and aloofness. There was something in it to set her heart
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beating. She yearned to it with her ears and her lips. Was it joy,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: menace, carelessness? She did not know, but this she did know, that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: however terrible it was personal to her. It was her unborn thought
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: strangely audible and felt rather than understood.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: On that day she did not see anybody either. She drove her charges home
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the evening listlessly and the beasts also were very quiet.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When the music came again she made no effort to discover where it came
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from. She only listened, and when the tune was ended she saw a figure
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rise from the fold of a little hill. The sunlight was gleaming from his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: arms and shoulders but the rest of his body was hidden by the bracken,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and he did not look at her as he went away playing softly on a double
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pipe.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The next day he did look at her. He stood waist-deep in greenery
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fronting her squarely. She had never seen so strange a face before. Her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eyes almost died on him as she gazed and he returned her look for a long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: minute with an intent, expressionless regard. His hair was a cluster of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brown curls, his nose was little and straight, and his wide mouth
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: drooped sadly at the corners. His eyes were wide and most mournful, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his forehead was very broad and white. His sad eyes and mouth almost
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: made her weep.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When he turned away he smiled at her, and it was as though the sun had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shone suddenly in a dark place, banishing all sadness and gloom. Then he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went mincingly away. As he went he lifted the slender double reed to his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lips and blew a few careless notes.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The next day he fronted her as before, looking down to her eyes from a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: short distance. He played for only a few moments, and fitfully, and then
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he came to her. When he left the bracken the girl suddenly clapped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her hands against her eyes affrighted. There was something different,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: terrible about him. The upper part of his body was beautiful, but the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lower part.... She dared not look at him again. She would have risen and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fled away but she feared he might pursue her, and the thought of such
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a chase and the inevitable capture froze her blood. The thought of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anything behind us is always terrible. The sound of pursuing feet is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: worse than the murder from which we fly--So she sat still and waited but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nothing happened. At last, desperately, she dropped her hands. He was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sitting on the ground a few paces from her. He was not looking at her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but far away sidewards across the spreading hill. His legs were crossed;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they were shaggy and hoofed like the legs of a goat: but she would not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: look at these because of his wonderful, sad, grotesque face. Gaiety is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good to look upon and an innocent face is delightful to our souls,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but no woman can resist sadness or weakness, and ugliness she dare
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not resist. Her nature leaps to be the comforter. It is her reason. It
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: exalts her to an ecstasy wherein nothing but the sacrifice of herself
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: has any proportion. Men are not fathers by instinct but by chance, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: women are mothers beyond thought, beyond instinct which is the father
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of thought. Motherliness, pity, self-sacrifice--these are the charges
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of her primal cell, and not even the discovery that men are comedians,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: liars, and egotists will wean her from this. As she looked at the pathos
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of his face she repudiated the hideousness of his body. The beast
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which is in all men is glossed by women; it is his childishness, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: destructive energy inseparable from youth and high spirits, and it is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: always forgiven by women, often forgotten, sometimes, and not rarely,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cherished and fostered.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: After a few moments of this silence he placed the reed to his lips and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: played a plaintive little air, and then he spoke to her in a strange
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: voice, coming like a wind from distant places.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What is your name, Shepherd Girl?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Caitilin, Ingin Ni Murrachu," she whispered.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Daughter of Murrachu," said he, "I have come from a far place where
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there are high hills. The men and maidens who follow their flocks in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that place know me and love me for I am the Master of the Shepherds.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They sing and dance and are glad when I come to them in the sunlight;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but in this country no people have done any reverence to me. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shepherds fly away when they hear my pipes in the pastures; the maidens
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: scream in fear when I dance to them in the meadows. I am very lonely in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this strange country. You also, although you danced to the music of my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pipes, have covered your face against me and made no reverence."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will do whatever you say if it is right," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You must not do anything because it is right, but because it is your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wish. Right is a word and Wrong is a word, but the sun shines in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: morning and the dew falls in the dusk without thinking of these words
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which have no meaning. The bee flies to the flower and the seed goes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: abroad and is happy. Is that right, Shepherd Girl?--it is wrong also.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I come to you because the bee goes to the flower--it is wrong! If I did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not come to you to whom would I go? There is no right and no wrong but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: only the will of the gods."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am afraid of you," said the girl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You fear me because my legs are shaggy like the legs of a goat. Look at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them well, O Maiden, and know that they are indeed the legs of a beast
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then you will not be afraid any more. Do you not love beasts? Surely
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you should love them for they yearn to you humbly or fiercely, craving
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: your hand upon their heads as I do. If I were not fashioned thus I would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not come to you because I would not need you. Man is a god and a brute.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He aspires to the stars with his head but his feet are contented in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the grasses of the field, and when he forsakes the brute upon which he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stands then there will be no more men and no more women and the immortal
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gods will blow this world away like smoke."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know what you want me to do," said the girl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I want you to want me. I want you to forget right and wrong; to be as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: happy as the beasts, as careless as the flowers and the birds. To live
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to the depths of your nature as well as to the heights. Truly there are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stars in the heights and they will be a garland for your forehead. But
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the depths are equal to the heights. Wondrous deep are the depths, very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fertile is the lowest deep. There are stars there also, brighter than
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the stars on high. The name of the heights is Wisdom and the name of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: depths is Love. How shall they come together and be fruitful if you do
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not plunge deeply and fearlessly? Wisdom is the spirit and the wings of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the spirit, Love is the shaggy beast that goes down. Gallantly he dives,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: below thought, beyond Wisdom, to rise again as high above these as he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had first descended. Wisdom is righteous and clean, but Love is unclean
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and holy. I sing of the beast and the descent: the great unclean purging
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: itself in fire: the thought that is not born in the measure or the ice
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or the head, but in the feet and the hot blood and the pulse of fury.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Crown of Life is not lodged in the sun: the wise gods have buried it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: deeply where the thoughtful will not find it, nor the good: but the Gay
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Ones, the Adventurous Ones, the Careless Plungers, they will bring it to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the wise and astonish them. All things are seen in the light--How shall
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: we value that which is easy to see? But the precious things which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: are hidden, they will be more precious for our search: they will be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beautiful with our sorrow: they will be noble because of our desire for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them. Come away with me, Shepherd Girl, through the fields, and we will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be careless and happy, and we will leave thought to find us when it can,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for that is the duty of thought, and it is more anxious to discover us
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: than we are to be found."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So Caitilin Ni Murrachu arose and went with him through the fields, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she did not go with him because of love, nor because his words had been
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: understood by her, but only because he was naked and unashamed.

text: CHAPTER VII
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: IT was on account of his daughter that Meehawl MacMurrachu had come to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: visit the Philosopher. He did not know what had become of her, and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: facts he had to lay before his adviser were very few.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He left the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath taking snuff under a pine tree
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and went into the house.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with all here," said he as he entered.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with yourself, Meehawl MacMurrachu," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am in great trouble this day, sir," said Meehawl, "and if you would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: give me an advice I'd be greatly beholden to you."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I can give you that," replied the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "None better than your honour and no trouble to you either. It was a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: powerful advice you gave me about the washboard, and if I didn't come
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: here to thank you before this it was not because I didn't want to come,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but that I couldn't move hand or foot by dint of the cruel rheumatism
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: put upon me by the Leprecauns of Gort na Cloca Mora, bad cess to them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for ever: twisted I was the way you'd get a squint in your eye if you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: only looked at me, and the pain I suffered would astonish you."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It would not," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No matter," said Meehawl. "What I came about was my young daughter
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Caitilin. Sight or light of her I haven't had for three days. My wife
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: said first, that it was the fairies had taken her, and then she said it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was a travelling man that had a musical instrument she went away with,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and after that she said, that maybe the girl was lying dead in the butt
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of a ditch with her eyes wide open, and she staring broadly at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: moon in the night time and the sun in the day until the crows would be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: finding her out."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher drew his chair closer to Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Daughters," said he, "have been a cause of anxiety to their parents
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ever since they were instituted. The flightiness of the female
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: temperament is very evident in those who have not arrived at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: years which teach how to hide faults and frailties, and, therefore,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: indiscretions bristle from a young girl the way branches do from a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bush."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The person who would deny that--" said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Female children, however, have the particular sanction of nature. They
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: are produced in astonishing excess over males, and may, accordingly,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be admitted as dominant to the male; but the well-proven law that the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: minority shall always control the majority will relieve our minds from a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fear which might otherwise become intolerable."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's true enough," said Meehawl. "Have you noticed, sir, that in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: litter of pups--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have not," said the Philosopher. "Certain trades and professions,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it is curious to note, tend to be perpetuated in the female line. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sovereign profession among bees and ants is always female, and publicans
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: also descend on the distaff side. You will have noticed that every
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: publican has three daughters of extraordinary charms. Lacking these
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: signs we would do well to look askance at such a man's liquor, divining
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that in his brew there will be an undue percentage of water, for if his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: primogeniture is infected how shall his honesty escape?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It would take a wise head to answer that," said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It would not," said the Philosopher. "Throughout nature the female
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tends to polygamy."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If," said Meehawl, "that unfortunate daughter of mine is lying dead in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a ditch--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It doesn't matter," said the Philosopher. "Many races have endeavoured
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to place some limits to this increase in females. Certain Oriental
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peoples have conferred the titles of divinity on crocodiles, serpents,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and tigers of the jungle, and have fed these with their surplusage
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of daughters. In China, likewise, such sacrifices are defended as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: honourable and economic practices. But, broadly speaking, if daughters
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have to be curtailed I prefer your method of losing them rather than the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: religio-hysterical compromises of the Orient."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I give you my word, sir," said Meehawl, "that I don't know what you are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: talking about at all."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That," said the Philosopher, "may be accounted for in three
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ways--firstly, there is a lack of cerebral continuity: that is, faulty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: attention; secondly, it might be due to a local peculiarity in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conformation of the skull, or, perhaps, a superficial instead of a deep
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: indenting of the cerebral coil; and thirdly--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Did you ever hear," said Meehawl, "of the man that had the scalp of his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: head blown off by a gun, and they soldered the bottom of a tin dish to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the top of his skull the way you could hear his brains ticking inside of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it for all the world like a Waterbury watch?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I did not," said the Philosopher. "Thirdly, it may--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's my daughter, Caitilin, sir," said Meehawl humbly. "Maybe she is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lying in the butt of a ditch and the crows picking her eyes out."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What did she die of?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My wife only put it that maybe she was dead, and that maybe she was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: taken by the fairies, and that maybe she went away with the travelling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man that had the musical instrument. She said it was a concertina, but I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: think myself it was a flute he had."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Who was this traveller?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I never saw him," said Meehawl, "but one day I went a few perches up
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the hill and I heard him playing--thin, squeaky music it was like you'd
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be blowing out of a tin whistle. I looked about for him everywhere, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not a bit of him could I see."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Eh?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I looked about--" said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I know," said the Philosopher. "Did you happen to look at your goats?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I couldn't well help doing that," said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What were they doing?" said the Philosopher eagerly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "They were bucking each other across the field, and standing on their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hind legs and cutting such capers that I laughed till I had a pain in my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stomach at the gait of them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "This is very interesting," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you tell me so?" said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do," said the Philosopher, "and for this reason-most of the races of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the world have at one time or another--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's my little daughter, Caitilin, sir," said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'm attending to her," the Philosopher replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I thank you kindly," returned Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher continued "Most of the races of the world have at one
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time or another been visited by this deity, whose title is the 'Great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: God Pan,' but there is no record of his ever having journeyed to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Ireland, and, certainly within historic times, he has not set foot on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these shores. He lived for a great number of years in Egypt, Persia,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and Greece, and although his empire is supposed to be world-wide, this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: universal sway has always been, and always will be, contested; but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nevertheless, however sharply his empire may be curtailed, he will never
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be without a kingdom wherein his exercise of sovereign rights will be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gladly and passionately acclaimed."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is he one of the old gods, sir?" said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He is," replied the Philosopher, "and his coming intends no good
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to this country. Have you any idea why he should have captured your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: daughter?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Not an idea in the world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is your daughter beautiful?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I couldn't tell you, because I never thought of looking at her that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: way. But she is a good milker, and as strong as a man. She can lift a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bag of meal under her arm easier than I can; but she's a timid creature
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for all that."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Whatever the reason is I am certain that he has the girl, and I am
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: inclined to think that he was directed to her by the Leprecauns of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Gort. You know they are at feud with you ever since their bird was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: killed?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am not likely to forget it, and they racking me day and night with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: torments."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You may be sure," said the Philosopher, "that if he's anywhere at all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it's at Gort na Cloca Mora he is, for, being a stranger, he wouldn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: know where to go unless he was directed, and they know every hole and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: corner of this countryside since ancient times. I'd go up myself and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have a talk with him, but it wouldn't be a bit of good, and it wouldn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be any use your going either. He has power over all grown people so that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they either go and get drunk or else they fall in love with every person
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they meet, and commit assaults and things I wouldn't like to be telling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you about. The only folk who can go near him at all are little children,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: because he has no power over them until they grow to the sensual age,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then he exercises lordship over them as over every one else. I'll
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: send my two children with a message to him to say that he isn't doing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the decent thing, and that if he doesn't let the girl alone and go back
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to his own country we'll send for Angus Og."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He'd make short work of him, I'm thinking."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He might surely; but he may take the girl for himself all the same."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, I'd sooner he had her than the other one, for he's one of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ourselves anyhow, and the devil you know is better than the devil you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: don't know."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Angus Og is a god," said the Philosopher severely.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I know that, sir," replied Meehawl; "it's only a way of talking I have.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But how will your honour get at Angus? for I heard say that he hadn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been seen for a hundred years, except one night only when he talked to a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man for half an hour on Kilmasheogue."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll find him, sure enough," replied the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll warrant you will," replied Meehawl heartily as he stood up. "Long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: life and good health to your honour," said he as he turned away.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher lit his pipe.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We live as long as we are let," said he, "and we get the health we
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: deserve. Your salutation embodies a reflection on death which is not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: philosophic. We must acquiesce in all logical progressions. The merging
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of opposites is completion. Life runs to death as to its goal, and we
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: should go towards that next stage of experience either carelessly as to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: what must be, or with a good, honest curiosity as to what may be."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's not much fun in being dead, sir," said Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "How do you know?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I know well enough," replied Meehawl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: WHEN the children leaped into the hole at the foot of the tree they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: found themselves sliding down a dark, narrow slant which dropped them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: softly enough into a little room. This room was hollowed out immediately
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: under the tree, and great care had been taken not to disturb any of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the roots which ran here and there through the chamber in the strangest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: criss-cross, twisted fashion. To get across such a place one had to walk
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: round, and jump over, and duck under perpetually. Some of the roots had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: formed themselves very conveniently into low seats and narrow, uneven
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tables, and at the bottom all the roots ran into the floor and away
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again in the direction required by their business. After the clear air
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: outside this place was very dark to the children's eyes, so that they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: could not see anything for a few minutes, but after a little time their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eyes became accustomed to the semiobscurity and they were able to see
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: quite well. The first things they became aware of were six small men who
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were seated on low roots. They were all dressed in tight green clothes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and little leathern aprons, and they wore tall green hats which wobbled
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when they moved. They were all busily engaged making shoes. One was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: drawing out wax ends on his knee, another was softening pieces of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leather in a bucket of water, another was polishing the instep of a shoe
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with a piece of curved bone, another was paring down a heel with a short
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: broad-bladed knife, and another was hammering wooden pegs into a sole.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He had all the pegs in his mouth, which gave him a widefaced, jolly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: expression, and according as a peg was wanted he blew it into his hand
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and hit it twice with his hammer, and then he blew another peg, and he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: always blew the peg with the right end uppermost, and never had to hit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it more than twice. He was a person well worth watching.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children had slid down so unexpectedly that they almost forgot their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good manners, but as soon as Seumas Beg discovered that he was really in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a room he removed his cap and stood up.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with all here," said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Leprecaun who had brought them lifted Brigid from the floor to which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: amazement still constrained her.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Sit down on that little root, child of my heart," said he, "and you can
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: knit stockings for us."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Yes, sir," said Brigid meekly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Leprecaun took four knitting needles and a ball of green wool from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the top of a high, horizontal root. He had to climb over one, go round
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: three and climb up two roots to get at it, and he did this so easily
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that it did not seem a bit of trouble. He gave the needles and wool to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Brigid Beg.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you know how to turn the heel, Brigid Beg?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, sir," said Brigid.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, I'll show you how when you come to it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The other six Leprecauns had ceased work and were looking at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children. Seumas turned to them.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God bless the work," said he politely.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: One of the Leprecauns, who had a grey, puckered face and a thin fringe
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of grey whisker very far under his chin, then spoke.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Come over here, Seumas Beg," said he, "and I'll measure you for a pair
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of shoes. Put your foot up on that root."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy did so, and the Leprecaun took the measure of his foot with a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wooden rule.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Now, Brigid Beg, show me your foot," and he measured her also. "They'll
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be ready for you in the morning."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you never do anything else but make shoes, sir?" said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We do not," replied the Leprecaun, "except when we want new clothes,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then we have to make them, but we grudge every minute spent making
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anything else except shoes, because that is the proper work for a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Leprecaun. In the night time we go about the country into people's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: houses and we clip little pieces off their money, and so, bit by bit,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: we get a crock of gold together, because, do you see, a Leprecaun has to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have a crock of gold so that if he's captured by men folk he may be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: able to ransom himself. But that seldom happens, because it's a great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: disgrace altogether to be captured by a man, and we've practiced so long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: dodging among the roots here that we can easily get away from them. Of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: course, now and again we are caught; but men are fools, and we always
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: escape without having to pay the ransom at all. We wear green clothes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: because it's the colour of the grass and the leaves, and when we sit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: down under a bush or lie in the grass they just walk by without noticing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: us."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Will you let me see your crock of gold?" said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Leprecaun looked at him fixedly for a moment.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you like griddle bread and milk?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I like it well," Seumas answered.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Then you had better have some," and the Leprecaun took a piece of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: griddle bread from the shelf and filled two saucers with milk.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: While the children were eating the Leprecauns asked them many questions
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What time do you get up in the morning?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Seven o'clock," replied Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And what do you have for breakfast?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Stirabout and milk," he replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's good food," said the Leprecaun. "What do you have for dinner?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Potatoes and milk," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's not bad at all," said the Leprecaun. "And what do you have for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: supper?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Brigid answered this time because her brother's mouth was full.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Bread and milk, sir," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's nothing better," said the Leprecaun.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And then we go to bed," continued Brigid.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why wouldn't you?" said the Leprecaun.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It was at this point the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath knocked on the tree
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: trunk and demanded that the children should be returned to her.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When she had gone away the Leprecauns held a consultation, whereat it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was decided that they could not afford to anger the Thin Woman and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Shee of Croghan Conghaile, so they shook hands with the children and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bade them good-bye. The Leprecaun who had enticed them away from home
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brought them back again, and on parting he begged the children to visit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Gort na Cloca Mora whenever they felt inclined.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's always a bit of griddle bread or potato cake, and a noggin of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: milk for a friend," said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are very kind, sir," replied Seumas, and his sister said the same
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: words.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: As the Leprecaun walked away they stood watching him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you remember," said Seumas, "the way he hopped and waggled his leg
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the last time he was here?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do so," replied Brigid.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, he isn't hopping or doing anything at all this time," said
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He's not in good humour to-night," said Brigid, "but I like him."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "So do I," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When they went into the house the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath was very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: glad to see them, and she baked a cake with currants in it, and also
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gave them both stir-about and potatoes; but the Philosopher did not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: notice that they had been away at all. He said at last that "talking was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bad wit, that women were always making a fuss, that children should be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fed, but not fattened, and that beds were meant to be slept in." The Thin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Woman replied "that he was a grisly old man without bowels, that she did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not know what she had married him for, that he was three times her age,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and that no one would believe what she had to put up with."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER IX
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: PURSUANT to his arrangement with Meehawl MacMurrachu, the Philosopher
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sent the children in search of Pan. He gave them the fullest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instructions as to how they should address the Sylvan Deity, and then,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: having received the admonishments of the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children departed in the early morning.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When they reached the clearing in the pine wood, through which the sun
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was blazing, they sat down for a little while to rest in the heat. Birds
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were continually darting down this leafy shaft, and diving away into the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: dark wood. These birds always had something in their beaks. One would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have a worm, or a snail, or a grasshopper, or a little piece of wool
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: torn off a sheep, or a scrap of cloth, or a piece of hay; and when they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had put these things in a certain place they flew up the sun-shaft again
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and looked for something else to bring home. On seeing the children each
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the birds waggled his wings, and made a particular sound. They said
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "caw" and "chip" and "twit" and "tut" and "what" and "pit"; and one,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whom the youngsters liked very much, always said "tit-tittit-tit-tit."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children were fond of him because he was so all-of-asudden. They
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: never knew where he was going to fly next, and they did not believe he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: knew himself. He would fly backwards and forwards, and up and down, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sideways and bawways--all, so to speak, in the one breath. He did this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: because he was curious to see what was happening everywhere, and, as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: something is always happening everywhere, he was never able to fly in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a straight line for more than the littlest distance. He was a cowardly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bird too, and continually fancied that some person was going to throw
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a stone at him from behind a bush, or a wall, or a tree, and these
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: imaginary dangers tended to make his journeyings still more wayward and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: erratic. He never flew where he wanted to go himself, but only where God
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: directed him, and so he did not fare at all badly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children knew each of the birds by their sounds, and always said
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these words to them when they came near. For a little time they had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: difficulty in saying the right word to the right bird, and sometimes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: said "chip" when the salutation should have been "tut." The birds always
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: resented this, and would scold them angrily, but after a little practice
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they never made any mistakes at all. There was one bird, a big, black
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fellow, who loved to be talked to. He used to sit on the ground beside
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the children, and say "caw" as long as they would repeat it after him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He often wasted a whole morning in talk, but none of the other birds
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: remained for more than a few minutes at a time. They were always busy
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the morning, but in the evening they had more leisure, and would stay
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and chat as long as the children wanted them. The awkward thing was that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the evening all the birds wanted to talk at the same moment, so that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the youngsters never knew which of them to answer. Seumas Beg got out
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of that difficulty for a while by learning to whistle their notes, but,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: even so, they spoke with such rapidity that he could not by any means
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: keep pace with them. Brigid could only whistle one note; it was a little
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: flat "whoo" sound, which the birds all laughed at, and after a few
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: trials she refused to whistle any more.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: While they were sitting two rabbits came to play about in the brush.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They ran round and round in a circle, and all their movements were very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: quick and twisty. Sometimes they jumped over each other six or seven
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: times in succession, and every now and then they sat upright on their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hind legs, and washed their faces with their paws. At other times they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: picked up a blade of grass, which they ate with great deliberation,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pretending all the time that it was a complicated banquet of cabbage
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leaves and lettuce.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: While the children were playing with the rabbits an ancient, stalwart
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he-goat came prancing through the bracken. He was an old acquaintance of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: theirs, and he enjoyed lying beside them to have his forehead scratched
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with a piece of sharp stick. His forehead was hard as rock, and the hair
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grew there as sparse as grass does on a wall, or rather the way moss
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grows on a wall--it was a mat instead of a crop. His horns were long and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: very sharp, and brilliantly polished. On this day the he-goat had two
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: chains around his neck--one was made of butter-cups and the other was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: made of daisies, and the children wondered to each other who it was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: could have woven these so carefully. They asked the he-goat this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: question, but he only looked at them and did not say a word. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children liked examining this goat's eyes; they were very big, and of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the queerest light-gray colour. They had a strange steadfast look, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had also at times a look of queer, deep intelligence, and at other times
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they had a fatherly and benevolent expression, and at other times
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again, especially when he looked sidewards, they had a mischievous,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: light-and-airy, daring, mocking, inviting and terrifying look; but he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: always looked brave and unconcerned. When the he-goat's forehead had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been scratched as much as he desired he arose from between the children
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and went pacing away lightly through the wood. The children ran after
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him and each caught hold of one of his horns, and he ambled and reared
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: between them while they danced along on his either side singing snatches
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of bird songs, and scraps of old tunes which the Thin Woman of Inis
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Magrath had learned among the people of the Shee.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In a little time they came to Gort na Cloca Mora, but here the he-goat
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: did not stop. They went past the big tree of the Leprecauns, through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a broken part of the hedge and into another rough field. The sun was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shining gloriously. There was scarcely a wind at all to stir the harsh
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grasses. Far and near was silence and warmth, an immense, cheerful
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peace. Across the sky a few light clouds sailed gently on a blue so vast
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that the eye failed before that horizon. A few bees sounded their deep
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: chant, and now and again a wasp rasped hastily on his journey. Than
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these there was no sound of any kind. So peaceful, innocent and safe did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: everything appear that it might have been the childhood of the world as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it was of the morning.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children, still clinging to the friendly goat, came near the edge
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the field, which here sloped more steeply to the mountain top. Great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: boulders, slightly covered with lichen and moss, were strewn about, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: around them the bracken and gorse were growing, and in every crevice of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these rocks there were plants whose little, tight-fisted roots gripped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a desperate, adventurous habitation in a soil scarcely more than half
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: an inch deep. At some time these rocks had been smitten so fiercely that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the solid granite surfaces had shattered into fragments. At one place
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a sheer wall of stone, ragged and battered, looked harshly out from the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thin vegetation. To this rocky wall the he-goat danced. At one place
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there was a hole in the wall covered by a thick brush. The goat pushed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his way behind this growth and disappeared. Then the children, curious
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to see where he had gone, pushed through also. Behind the bush they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: found a high, narrow opening, and when they had rubbed their legs, which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: smarted from the stings of nettles, thistles and gorse prickles, they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went into the hole which they thought was a place the goat had for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sleeping in on cold, wet nights. After a few paces they found the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: passage was quite comfortably big, and then they saw a light, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in another moment they were blinking at the god Pan and Caitilin Ni
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Murrachu.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Caitilin knew them at once and came forward with welcome.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "O, Seumas Beg," she cried reproachfully, "how dirty you have let your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: feet get. Why don't you walk in the grassy places? And you, Brigid, have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a right to be ashamed of yourself to have your hands the way they are.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Come over here at once."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Every child knows that every grown female person in the world has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: authority to wash children and to give them food; that is what grown
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: people were made for, consequently Seumas and Brigid Beg submitted to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the scouring for which Caitilin made instant preparation. When they were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cleaned she pointed to a couple of flat stones against the wall of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cave and bade them sit down and be good, and this the children did,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fixing their eyes on Pan with the cheerful gravity and curiosity which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good-natured youngsters always give to a stranger.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan, who had been lying on a couch of dried grass, sat up and bent an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: equally cheerful regard on the children.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shepherd Girl," said he, "who are those children?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "They are the children of the Philosophers of Coilla Doraca; the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Grey Woman of Dun Gortin and the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath are their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mothers, and they are decent, poor children, God bless them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What have they come here for?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You will have to ask themselves that."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan looked at them smilingly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What have you come here for, little children?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The children questioned one another with their eyes to see which of them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would reply, and then Seumas Beg answered:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My father sent me to see you, sir, and to say that you were not doing a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good thing in keeping Caitilin Ni Murrachu away from her own place."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Brigid Beg turned to Caitilin-"Your father came to see our father, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he said that he didn't know what had become of you at all, and that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: maybe you were lying flat in a ditch with the black crows picking at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: your flesh."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And what," said Pan, "did your father say to that?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He told us to come and ask her to go home."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you love your father, little child?" said Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Brigid Beg thought for a moment. "I don't know, sir," she replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He doesn't mind us at all," broke in Seumas Beg, "and so we don't know
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whether we love him or not."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I like Caitilin," said Brigid, "and I like you."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "So do I," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I like you also, little children," said Pan. "Come over here and sit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beside me, and we will talk."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So the two children went over to Pan and sat down one each side of him,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and he put his arms about them. "Daughter of Murrachu," said he, "is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there no food in the house for guests?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There is a cake of bread, a little goat's milk and some cheese," she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: replied, and she set about getting these things.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I never ate cheese," said Seumas. "Is it good?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Surely it is," replied Pan. "The cheese that is made from goat's milk
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is rather strong, and it is good to be eaten by people who live in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: open air, but not by those who live in houses, for such people do not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have any appetite. They are poor creatures whom I do not like."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I like eating," said Seumas.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "So do I," said Pan. "All good people like eating. Every person who is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hungry is a good person, and every person who is not hungry is a bad
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: person. It is better to be hungry than rich."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Caitilin having supplied the children with food, seated herself in front
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of them. "I don't think that is right," said she. "I have always been
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hungry, and it was never good."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If you had always been full you would like it even less," he replied,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "because when you are hungry you are alive, and when you are not hungry
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you are only half alive."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "One has to be poor to be hungry," replied Caitilin. "My father is poor
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and gets no good of it but to work from morning to night and never to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stop doing that."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is bad for a wise person to be poor," said Pan, "and it is bad for a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fool to be rich. A rich fool will think of nothing else at first but to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: find a dark house wherein to hide away, and there he will satisfy his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hunger, and he will continue to do that until his hunger is dead and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he is no better than dead but a wise person who is rich will carefully
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: preserve his appetite. All people who have been rich for a long time, or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: who are rich from birth, live a great deal outside of their houses, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: so they are always hungry and healthy."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Poor people have no time to be wise," said Caitilin.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "They have time to be hungry," said Pan. "I ask no more of them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My father is very wise," said Seumas Beg.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "How do you know that, little boy?" said Pan.
