title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Because he is always talking," replied Seumas. "Do you always listen,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my dear?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, sir," said Seumas; "I go to sleep when he talks."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is very clever of you," said Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I go to sleep too," said Brigid.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is clever of you also, my darling. Do you go to sleep when your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mother talks?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Oh, no," she answered. "If we went to sleep then our mother would pinch
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: us and say that we were a bad breed."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I think your mother is wise," said Pan. "What do you like best in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: world, Seumas Beg?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy thought for a moment and replied: "I don't know, sir."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan also thought for a little time.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know what I like best either," said he. "What do you like best
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the world, Shepherd Girl?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Caitilin's eyes were fixed on his.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know yet," she answered slowly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "May the gods keep you safe from that knowledge," said Pan gravely.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why would you say that?" she replied. "One must find out all things,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and when we find out a thing we know if it is good or bad."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is the beginning of knowledge," said Pan, "but it is not the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beginning of wisdom."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What is the beginning of wisdom?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is carelessness," replied Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And what is the end of wisdom?" said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not know," he answered, after a little pause.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is it greater carelessness?" she enquired.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not know, I do not know," said he sharply. "I am tired of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: talking," and, so saying, he turned his face away from them and lay down
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on the couch.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Caitilin in great concern hurried the children to the door of the cave
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and kissed them good-bye.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Pan is sick," said the boy gravely.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I hope he will be well soon again," the girl murmured.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Yes, yes," said Caitilin, and she ran back quickly to her lord.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: BOOK II. THE PHILOSOPHER'S JOURNEY
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER X
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: WHEN the children reached home they told the Philosopher-the result of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their visit. He questioned them minutely as to the appearance of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan, how he had received them, and what he had said in defence of his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: iniquities; but when he found that Pan had not returned any answer
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to his message he became very angry. He tried to persuade his wife to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: undertake another embassy setting forth his abhorrence and defiance of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the god, but the Thin Woman replied sourly that she was a respectable
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: married woman, that having been already bereaved of her wisdom she had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: no desire to be further curtailed of her virtue, that a husband would go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: any length to asperse his wife's reputation, and that although she was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: married to a fool her self-respect had survived even that calamity. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Philosopher pointed out that her age, her appearance, and her tongue
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were sufficient guarantees of immunity against the machinations of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: either Pan or slander, and that he had no personal feelings in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: matter beyond a scientific and benevolent interest in the troubles
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of Meehawl MacMurrachu; but this was discounted by his wife as the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: malignant and subtle tactics customary to all husbands.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Matters appeared to be thus at a deadlock so far as they were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: immediately concerned, and the Philosopher decided that he would lay the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: case before Angus Og and implore his protection and assistance on behalf
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the Clann MacMurrachu. He therefore directed the Thin Woman to bake
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him two cakes of bread, and set about preparations for a journey.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman baked the cakes, and put them in a bag, and early on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: following morning the Philosopher swung this bag over his shoulder, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went forth on his quest.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: When he came to the edge of the pine wood he halted for a few moments,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not being quite certain of his bearings, and then went forward again in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the direction of Gort na Cloca Mora. It came into his mind as he crossed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Gort that he ought to call on the Leprecauns and have a talk with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them, but a remembrance of Meehawl MacMurrachu and the troubles under
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which he laboured (all directly to be traced to the Leprecauns) hardened
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his heart against his neighbours, so that he passed by the yew tree
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: without any stay. In a short time he came to the rough, heather-clumped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: field wherein the children had found Pan, and as he was proceeding up
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the hill, he saw Caitilin Ni Murrachu walking a little way in front with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a small vessel in her hand. The she-goat which she had just milked was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bending again to the herbage, and as Caitilin trod lightly in front of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him the Philosopher closed his eyes in virtuous anger and opened them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again in a not unnatural curiosity, for the girl had no clothes on. He
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: watched her going behind the brush and disappearing in the cleft of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rock, and his anger, both with her and Pan, mastering him he forsook
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the path of prudence which soared to the mountain top, and followed that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leading to the cave. The sound of his feet brought Caitilin out hastily,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but he pushed her by with a harsh word. "Hussy," said he, and he went
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: into the cave where Pan was.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: As he went in he already repented of his harshness and said "The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: human body is an aggregation of flesh and sinew, around a central bony
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: structure. The use of clothing is primarily to protect this organism
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from rain and cold, and it may not be regarded as the banner of morality
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: without danger to this fundamental premise. If a person does not desire
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to be so protected who will quarrel with an honourable liberty? Decency
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is not clothing but Mind. Morality is behaviour. Virtue is thought; I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have often fancied," he continued to Pan, whom he was now confronting,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "that the effect of clothing on mind must be very considerable, and that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it must have a modifying rather than an expanding effect, or, even, an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: intensifying as against an exuberant effect. With clothing the whole
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: environment is immediately affected. The air, which is our proper
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: medium, is only filtered to our bodies in an abated and niggardly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fashion which can scarcely be as beneficial as the generous and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: unintermitted elemental play. The question naturally arises whether
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: clothing is as unknown to nature as we have fancied? Viewed as a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: protective measure against atmospheric rigour we find that many
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: creatures grow, by their own central impulse, some kind of exterior
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: panoply which may be regarded as their proper clothing. Bears, cats,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: dogs, mice, sheep and beavers are wrapped in fur, hair, fell, fleece or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pelt, so these creatures cannot by any means be regarded as being naked.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Crabs, cockroaches, snails and cockles have ordered around them a crusty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: habiliment, wherein their original nakedness is only to be discovered by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: force, and other creatures have similarly provided themselves with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: some species of covering. Clothing, therefore, is not an art, but an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instinct, and the fact that man is born naked and does not grow his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: clothing upon himself from within but collects it from various distant
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and haphazard sources is not any reason to call this necessity an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instinct for decency. These, you will admit, are weighty reflections and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: worthy of consideration before we proceed to the wide and thorny subject
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of moral and immoral action. Now, what is virtue?" Pan, who had listened
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with great courtesy to these remarks, here broke in on the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Virtue," said he, "is the performance of pleasant actions."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher held the statement for a moment on his forefinger.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And what, then, is vice?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is vicious," said Pan, "to neglect the performance of pleasant
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: actions."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If this be so," the other commented, "philosophy has up to the present
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been on the wrong track."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is so," said Pan. "Philosophy is an immoral practice because it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: suggests a standard of practice impossible of being followed, and which,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: if it could be followed, would lead to the great sin of sterility."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The idea of virtue," said the Philosopher, with some indignation, "has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: animated the noblest intellects of the world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It has not animated them," replied Pan; "it has hypnotised them so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that they have conceived virtue as repression and self-sacrifice as an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: honourable thing instead of the suicide which it is."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Indeed," said the Philosopher; "this is very interesting, and if it is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: true the whole conduct of life will have to be very much simplified."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Life is already very simple," said Pan; "it is to be born and to die,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and in the interval to eat and drink, to dance and sing, to marry and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beget children."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "But it is simply materialism," cried the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why do you say 'but'?" replied Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is sheer, unredeemed animalism," continued his visitor.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is any name you please to call it," replied Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You have proved nothing," the Philosopher shouted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What can be sensed requires no proof."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You leave out the new thing," said the Philosopher. "You leave out
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brains. I believe in mind above matter. Thought above emotion. Spirit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: above flesh."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Of course you do," said Pan, and he reached for his oaten pipe.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher ran to the opening of the passage and thrust Caitilin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: aside. "Hussy," said he fiercely to her, and he darted out.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: As he went up the rugged path he could hear the pipes of Pan, calling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and sobbing and making high merriment on the air.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER XI
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "SHE does not deserve to be rescued," said the Philosopher, "but I will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rescue her. Indeed," he thought a moment later, "she does not want to be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rescued, and, therefore, I will rescue her."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: As he went down the road her shapely figure floated before his eyes as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beautiful and simple as an old statue. He wagged his head angrily at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: apparition, but it would not go away. He tried to concentrate his mind
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on a deep, philosophical maxim, but her disturbing image came between
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him and his thought, blotting out the latter so completely that a moment
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: after he had stated his aphorism he could not remember what it had been.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Such a condition of mind was so unusual that it bewildered him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is a mind, then, so unstable," said he, "that a mere figure, an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: animated geometrical arrangement can shake it from its foundations?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The idea horrified him: he saw civilisation building its temples over a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: volcano...
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "A puff," said he, "and it is gone. Beneath all is chaos and red
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anarchy, over all a devouring and insistent appetite. Our eyes tell
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: us what to think about, and our wisdom is no more than a catalogue of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sensual stimuli."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He would have been in a state of deep dejection were it not that through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his perturbation there bubbled a stream of such amazing well-being as he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had not felt since childhood. Years had toppled from his shoulders. He
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: left one pound of solid matter behind at every stride. His very skin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grew flexuous, and he found a pleasure in taking long steps such as he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: could not have accounted for by thought. Indeed, thought was the one
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing he felt unequal to, and it was not precisely that he could not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: think but that he did not want to. All the importance and authority
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of his mind seemed to have faded away, and the activity which had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: once belonged to that organ was now transferred to his eyes. He saw,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: amazedly, the sunshine bathing the hills and the valleys. A bird in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the hedge held him--beak, head, eyes, legs, and the wings that tapered
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: widely at angles to the wind. For the first time in his life he really
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: saw a bird, and one minute after it had flown away he could have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: reproduced its strident note. With every step along the curving road
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the landscape was changing. He saw and noted it almost in an ecstasy. A
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sharp hill jutted out into the road, it dissolved into a sloping meadow,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rolled down into a valley and then climbed easily and peacefully into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a hill again. On this side a clump of trees nodded together in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: friendliest fashion. Yonder a solitary tree, well-grown and clean, was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: contented with its own bright company. A bush crouched tightly on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ground as though, at a word, it would scamper from its place and chase
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rabbits across the sward with shouts and laughter. Great spaces of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sunshine were everywhere, and everywhere there were deep wells of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shadow; and the one did not seem more beautiful than the other. That
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sunshine! Oh, the glory of it, the goodness and bravery of it, how
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: broadly and grandly it shone, without stint, without care; he saw its
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: measureless generosity and gloried in it as though himself had been the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: flinger of that largesse. And was he not? Did the sunlight not stream
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from his head and life from his finger-tips? Surely the well-being that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was in him did bubble out to an activity beyond the universe. Thought!
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Oh! the petty thing! but motion! emotion! these were the realities. To
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: feel, to do, to stride forward in elation chanting a paean of triumphant
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: life!
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: After a time he felt hungry, and thrusting his hand into his wallet he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: broke off a piece of one of his cakes and looked about for a place where
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he might happily eat it. By the side of the road there was a well; just
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a little corner filled with water. Over it was a rough stone coping, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: around, hugging it on three sides almost from sight, were thick, quiet
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bushes. He would not have noticed the well at all but for a thin stream,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the breadth of two hands, which tiptoed away from it through a field.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: By this well he sat down and scooped the water in his hand and it tasted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He was eating his cake when a sound touched his ear from some distance,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and shortly a woman came down the path carrying a vessel in her hand to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: draw water.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: She was a big, comely woman, and she walked as one who had no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: misfortunes and no misgivings. When she saw the Philosopher sitting by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the well she halted a moment in surprise and then came forward with a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good-humoured smile.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Good morrow to you, sir," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Good morrow to you too, ma'am," replied the Philosopher. "Sit down
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beside me here and eat some of my cake."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why wouldn't I, indeed," said the woman, and she did sit beside him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher cracked a large piece off his cake and gave it to her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and she ate some.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's a taste on that cake," said she. "Who made it?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My wife did," he replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, now!" said she, looking at him. "Do you know, you don't look a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bit like a married man."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Not a bit. A married man looks comfortable and settled: he looks
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: finished, if you understand me, and a bachelor looks unsettled and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: funny, and he always wants to be running round seeing things. I'd know a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: married man from a bachelor any day."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "How would you know that?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Easily," said she, with a nod. "It's the way they look at a woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: A married man looks at you quietly as if he knew all about you. There
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: isn't any strangeness about him with a woman at all; but a bachelor man
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: looks at you very sharp and looks away and then looks back again, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: way you'd know he was thinking about you and didn't know what you were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thinking about him; and so they are always strange, and that's why women
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: like them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why!" said the Philosopher, astonished, "do women like bachelors better
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: than married men?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Of course they do," she replied heartily. "They wouldn't look at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: side of the road a married man was on if there was a bachelor man on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: other side."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "This," said the Philosopher earnestly, "is very interesting."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And the queer thing is," she continued, "that when I came up the road
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and saw you I said to myself 'it's a bachelor man.' How long have you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been married, now?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know," said the Philosopher. "Maybe it's ten years."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And how many children would you have, mister?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Two," he replied, and then corrected himself, "No, I have only one."

text: What you do is, you go out from your house and walk straight away in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: any direction with your shadow behind you so long as it is towards a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mountain, for the gods will not stay in a valley or a level plain, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: only in high places; and then, if the god wants you to see him, you will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: go to his rath as direct as if you knew where it was, for he will be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leading you with an airy thread reaching from his own place to wherever
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you are, and if he doesn't want to see you, you will never find out
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: where he is, not if you were to walk for a year or twenty years."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "How do you know he wants to see you?" said the second man.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why wouldn't he want?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Maybe, Mister Honey," said the woman, "you are a holy sort of a man
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that a god would like well."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why would I be that?" said the Philosopher. "The gods like a man
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whether he's holy or not if he's only decent."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Ah, well, there's plenty of that sort," said the first man. "What do
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you happen to have in your bag, stranger?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

text: baked for my journey."

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

text: have a taste of everybody's cake."

author: Stephens, James

text: "I will, and welcome," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: second man. "That woman hasn't got all the hunger of the world."

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to moisten the cake--Whoh, you devil," he roared at the ass, and the ass
title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

text: "Hike, you beast, you," shouted the man, and the ass at once hiked, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he did it in a way that brought him close to the grass. The first man
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: took a tin can out of the cart and climbed over the little wall for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the ass did not say a word, he only hiked still more which brought him
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: directly on to the grass, and when the man climbed over the wall the ass
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: commenced to crop the grass. There was a spider sitting on a hot stone
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the grass. He had a small body and wide legs, and he wasn't doing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anything.

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: walking on me, or lying down on me, or running over me with the wheels
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of a cart."

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

text: "She'd eat me," said the spider, "and, anyhow, the competition on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wall is dreadful, and the flies are getting wiser and timider every
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: season. Have you got a wife yourself, now?"
title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

text: that you hate her."

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: away from them," and so saying he began to move all his legs at once in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the direction of the wall. "You can only die once," said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If your wife was an ass she wouldn't eat you," said the ass.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "She'd be doing something else then," replied the spider, and he climbed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: up the wall.

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

text: "Why do you say that?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We were having a great argument along the road, and if we were to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be talking from now to the dav of doom that argument would never be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: finished."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It must have been a great argument. Was it about predestination or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: where consciousness comes from?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That's not a great argument," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Isn't it," said the woman. "For seven days and six nights we didn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: talk about anything else, and that's a great argument or I'd like to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: know what is."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "But where is the trouble, ma'am?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's this," she replied, "that I can't make up my mind which of the men
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I'll take, for I like one as well as the other and better, and I'd as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: soon have one as the other and rather."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's a hard case," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is," said the woman, "and I'm sick and sorry with the trouble of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And why did you say that I had come up in a good minute?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Because, Mister Honey, when a woman has two men to choose from she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: doesn't know what to do, for two men always become like brothers so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that you wouldn't know which of them was which: there isn't any more
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: difference between two men than there is between a couple of hares. But
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when there's three men to choose from, there's no trouble at all; and so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I say that it's yourself I'll marry this night and no one else--and let
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you two men be sitting quiet in your places, for I'm telling you what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I'll do and that's the end of it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll give you my word," said the first man, "that I'm just as glad as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you are to have it over and done with."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Moidered I was," said the second man, "with the whole argument, and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this and that of it, and you not able to say a word but--maybe I will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and maybe I won't, and this is true and that is true, and why not to me
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and why not to him--I'll get a sleep this night."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher was perplexed.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The woman turned round on him angrily.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Don't be making any argument with me now," said she, "for I won't stand
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his companion.

author: Stephens, James

text: "Give that man a clout in the jaw," said he.

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: angrily.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Keep your hands to yourself," said she, "or it'll be the worse for you.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and thinking each one according to his nature. The Philosopher's mind,
title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

text: these new circumstances, but without much result. There was a flutter at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his heart which was terrifying, but not unpleasant. Quickening through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his apprehension was an expectancy which stirred his pulses into speed.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brain that he did not realize he was unable to think and that he was
title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

text: say a word to you, for I can see that you are not used to travelling."

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lay, and every moment he stumbled into a patch of heather or prickly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: furze. The ground was very uneven with unexpected mounds and deep
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: one side there was a dark opening in the rock, so he said: "I will go

title: The Crock of Gold

text: CAITILIN NI MURRACHU was sitting alone in the little cave behind Gort na
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Cloca Mora. Her companion had gone out as was his custom to walk in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sunny morning and to sound his pipe in desolate, green spaces whence,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: perhaps, the wanderer of his desire might hear the guiding sweetness. As
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she sat she was thinking. The last few days had awakened her body, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had also awakened her mind, for with the one awakening comes the other.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The despondency which had touched her previously when tending her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: father's cattle came to her again, but recognizably now. She knew the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing which the wind had whispered in the sloping field and for which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she had no name--it was Happiness. Faintly she shadowed it forth,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but yet she could not see it. It was only a pearl-pale wraith, almost
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: formless, too tenuous to be touched by her hands, and too aloof to be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: spoken to. Pan had told her that he was the giver of happiness, but he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had given her only unrest and fever and a longing which could not be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: satisfied. Again there was a want, and she could not formulate, or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: even realize it with any closeness. Her new-born Thought had promised
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: everything, even as Pan, and it had given--she could not say that it had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: given her nothing or anything. Its limits were too quickly divinable.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: She had found the Tree of Knowledge, but about on every side a great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wall soared blackly enclosing her in from the Tree of Life--a wall which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her thought was unable to surmount even while instinct urged that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it must topple before her advance; but instinct may not advance when
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thought has schooled it in the science of unbelief; and this wall will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not be conquered until Thought and Instinct are wed, and the first son
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of that bridal will be called The Scaler of the Wall.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So, after the quiet weariness of ignorance, the unquiet weariness
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of thought had fallen upon her. That travail of mind which, through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: countless generations, has throed to the birth of an ecstasy, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: prophecy which humanity has sworn must be fulfilled, seeing through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whatever mists and doubtings the vision of a gaiety wherein the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: innocence of the morning will not any longer be strange to our maturity.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: While she was so thinking Pan returned, a little disheartened that he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had found no person to listen to his pipings. He had been seated but a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: little time when suddenly, from without, a chorus of birds burst into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: joyous singing. Limpid and liquid cadenzas, mellow flutings, and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sweet treble of infancy met and danced and piped in the airy soundings.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: A round, soft tenderness of song rose and fell, broadened and soared,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then the high flight was snatched, eddied a moment, and was borne
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: away to a more slender and wonderful loftiness, until, from afar, that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thrilling song turned on the very apex of sweetness, dipped steeply and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: flashed its joyous return to the exultations of its mates below, rolling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: an ecstasy of song which for one moment gladdened the whole world and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the sad people who moved thereon; then the singing ceased as suddenly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: as it began, a swift shadow darkened the passage, and Angus Og came into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the cave.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: movement towards rising, but instantly sank back again to his negligent,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: easy posture.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The god was slender and as swift as a wind. His hair swung about his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: face like golden blossoms. His eyes were mild and dancing and his lips
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: smiled with quiet sweetness. About his head there flew perpetually a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ring of singing birds, and when he spoke his voice came sweetly from a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: centre of sweetness.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Health to you, daughter of Murrachu," said he, and he sat down.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not know you, sir," the terrified girl whispered.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I cannot be known until I make myself known," he replied. "I am called
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Infinite Joy, O daughter of Murrachu, and I am called Love."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The girl gazed doubtfully from one to the other.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan looked up from his pipes.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I also am called Love," said he gently, "and I am called Joy."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Angus Og looked for the first time at Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Singer of the Vine," said he, "I know your names-they are Desire and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: upon my pastures and my quiet fields?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan replied mildly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The mortal gods move by the Immortal Will, and, therefore, I am here."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And I am here," said Angus.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Give me a sign," said Pan, "that I must go."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Angus Og lifted his hand and from without there came again the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: triumphant music of the birds.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: saying so, he made obeisance to the great mother.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the thin voices of the goats.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is a sign," said he, "the voice of Demeter speaking from the earth,"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and he also bowed deeply to the mother of the world.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Again Angus Og lifted his hand, and in it there appeared a spear, bright
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and very terrible.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But Pan only said, "Can a spear divine the Eternal Will?" and Angus Og
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: put his weapon aside, and he said: "The girl will choose between us, for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Divine Mood shines in the heart of man."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Then Caitilin Ni Murrachu came forward and sat between the gods, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Pan stretched out his hand and drew her to him, so that she sat resting
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: against his shoulder and his arm was about her body.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is the difference between us," replied Angus Og. "She will judge."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shepherd Girl," said Pan, pressing her with his arm, "you will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: judge between us. Do you know what is the greatest thing in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: world?--because it is of that you will have to judge."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have heard," the girl replied, "two things called the greatest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: things. You," she continued to Pan, "said it was Hunger, and long ago my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: father said that Commonsense was the greatest thing in the world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have not told you," said Angus Og, "what I consider is the greatest
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing in the world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It is your right to speak," said Pan.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The greatest thing in the world," said Angus Og, "is the Divine
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Imagination."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Now," said Pan, "we know all the greatest things and we can talk of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The daughter of Murrachu," continued Angus Og, "has told us what you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: think and what her father thinks, but she has not told us what she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thinks herself. Tell us, Caitilin Ni Murrachu, what you think is the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: greatest thing in the world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So Caitilin Ni Murrachu thought for a few moments and then replied
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: timidly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I think that Happiness is the greatest thing in the world," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Hearing this they sat in silence for a little time, and then Angus
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Og spoke again "The Divine Imagination may only be known through the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thoughts of His creatures. A man has said Commonsense and a woman has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: male and female, for Commonsense is Thought and Happiness is Emotion,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and until they embrace in Love the will of Immensity cannot be fruitful.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: For, behold, there has been no marriage of humanity since time began.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Men have but coupled with their own shadows. The desire that sprang from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their heads they pursued, and no man has yet known the love of a woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: And women have mated with the shadows of their own hearts, thinking
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fondly that the arms of men were about them. I saw my son dancing with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: an Idea, and I said to him, 'With what do you dance, my son?' and he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: replied, 'I make merry with the wife of my affection,' and truly she was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shaped as a woman is shaped, but it was an Idea he danced with and not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a woman. And presently he went away to his labours, and then his Idea
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: arose and her humanity came upon her so that she was clothed with beauty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and terror, and she went apart and danced with the servant of my son,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and there was great joy of that dancing--for a person in the wrong place
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is an Idea and not a person. Man is Thought and woman is Intuition, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they have never mated. There is a gulf between them and it is called
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Fear, and what they fear is, that their strengths shall be taken from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them and they may no longer be tyrants. The Eternal has made love blind,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for it is not by science, but by intuition alone, that he may come to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his beloved; but desire, which is science, has many eyes and sees so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: vastly that he passes his love in the press, saying there is no love,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and he propagates miserably on his own delusions. The finger-tips are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: guided by God, but the devil looks through the eyes of all creatures so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that they may wander in the errors of reason and justify themselves
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of their wanderings. The desire of a man shall be Beauty, but he has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fashioned a slave in his mind and called it Virtue. The desire of a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: woman shall be Wisdom, but she has formed a beast in her blood and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: called it Courage: but the real virtue is courage, and the real courage
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is liberty, and the real liberty is wisdom, and Wisdom is the son of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and Happiness."

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: silence in the little cave. Caitilin had covered her face with her hands
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and would not look at him, but Pan drew the girl closer to his side and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

text: this place?"

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to do," said she. "Why do you both want me? I have given myself to Pan,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and his arms are about me."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I want you," said Angus Og, "because the world has forgotten me. In all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my nation there is no remembrance of me. I, wandering on the hills of my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: country, am lonely indeed. I am the desolate god forbidden to utter
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my happy laughter. I hide the silver of my speech and the gold of my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: merriment. I live in the holes of the rocks and the dark caves of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sea. I weep in the morning because I may not laugh, and in the evening I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: go abroad and am not happy. Where I have kissed a bird has flown; where
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his nets and sold them in the market-places. Who will deliver me from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Thought, from the base holiness of Intellect, the maker of chains

author: Stephens, James

text: and traps? Who will save me from the holy impurity of Emotion, whose
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ornament her lusts and my little leaves to shrivel on the breasts of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: infamy? Lo, I am sealed in the caves of nonentity until the head and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: heart shall come together in fruitfulness, until Thought has wept for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Love, and Emotion has purified herself to meet her lover. Tirna-nog is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the heart of a man and the head of a woman. Widely they are separated.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Self-centred they stand, and between them the seas of space are flooding
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: desolately. No voice can shout across those shores. No eye can bridge
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them, nor any desire bring them together until the blind god shall find
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them on the wavering stream--not as an arrow searches straightly from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a bow, but gently, imperceptibly as a feather on the wind reaches the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ground on a hundred starts; not with the compass and the chart, but by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the breath of the Almighty which blows from all quarters without care
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and without ceasing. Night and day it urges from the outside to the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: inside. It gathers ever to the centre. From the far without to the deep

author: Stephens, James

text: within, trembling from the body to the soul until the head of a woman
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the heart of a man are filled with the Divine Imagination. Hymen,
title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the minds that do not labour. Sweetly I sing on the hillside. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the murmur of their own veins, and be enchanted with the wisdom of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: flashes, that the hand of Innocence may reach to the stars, that the

author: Stephens, James

text: WHICH is, the Earth or the creatures that move upon it, the more
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: important? This is a question prompted solely by intellectual arrogance,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for in life there is no greater and no less. The thing that is has
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: justified its own importance by mere existence, for that is the great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and equal achievement. If life were arranged for us from without such a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: question of supremacy would assume importance, but life is always from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: within, and is modified or extended by our own appetites, aspirations,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and central activities. From without we get pollen and the refreshment
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of space and quietude--it is sufficient. We might ask, is the Earth
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anything more than an extension of our human consciousness, or are we,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: moving creatures, only projections of the Earth's antennae? But these
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: matters have no value save as a field wherein Thought, like a wise lamb,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: may frolic merrily. And all would be very well if Thought would but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: continue to frolic, instead of setting up first as locum tenens for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Intuition and sticking to the job, and afterwards as the counsel and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: critic of Omnipotence. Everything has two names, and everything is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: twofold. The name of male Thought as it faces the world is Philosophy,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but the name it bears in Tirna-nog is Delusion. Female Thought is called
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Socialism on earth, but in Eternity it is known as Illusion; and this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is so because there has been no matrimony of minds, but only an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hermaphroditic propagation of automatic ideas, which in their due
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rotation assume dominance and reign severely. To the world this system
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of thought, because it is consecutive, is known as Logic, but Eternity
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: has written it down in the Book of Errors as Mechanism: for life may not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be consecutive, but explosive and variable, else it is a shackled and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: timorous slave.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: One of the great troubles of life is that Reason has taken charge of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: administration of Justice, and by mere identification it has achieved
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the crown and sceptre of its master. But the imperceptible usurpation
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was recorded, and discriminating minds understand the chasm which still
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: divides the pretender Law from the exiled King. In a like manner, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with feigned humility, the Cold Demon advanced to serve Religion, and by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: guile and violence usurped her throne; but the pure in heart still fly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from the spectre Theology to dance in ecstasy before the starry and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eternal goddess. Statecraft, also, that tender Shepherd of the Flocks,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: has been despoiled of his crook and bell, and wanders in unknown
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: desolation while, beneath the banner of Politics, Reason sits howling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: over an intellectual chaos.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Justice is the maintaining of equilibrium. The blood of Cain must cry,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not from the lips of the Avenger, but from the aggrieved Earth herself
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: who demands that atonement shall be made for a disturbance of her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: consciousness. All justice is, therefore, readjustment. A thwarted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: consciousness has every right to clamour for assistance, but not for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: punishment. This latter can only be sought by timorous and egotistic
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Intellect, which sees the Earth from which it has emerged and into which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it must return again in its own despite, and so, being self-centred and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: envious and a renegade from life, Reason is more cruelly unjust, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: more timorous than any other manifestation of the divinely erratic
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: energy--erratic, because, as has been said, "the crooked roads are the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: roads of genius." Nature grants to all her creatures an unrestricted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: liberty, quickened by competitive appetite, to succeed or to fail; save
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: only to Reason, her Demon of Order, which can do neither, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whose wings she has clipped for some reason with which I am not yet
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: acquainted. It may be that an unrestricted mentality would endanger
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her own intuitive perceptions by shackling all her other organs of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: perception, or annoy her by vexatious efforts at creative rivalry.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It will, therefore, be understood that when the Leprecauns of Gort
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
