text: "Not far," said the boy. "You could see my mother's house from this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: place if you were as tall as a tree, and even from the ground you can
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: see a shape of smoke yonder that floats over our cottage."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher looked but could see nothing.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My eyes are not as good as yours are," said he, "because I am getting
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: old."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What does it feel like to be old?" said the boy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It feels stiff like," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is that all?" said the boy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know," the Philosopher replied after a few moments' silence.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Can you tell me what it looks like to be young?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why not?" said the boy, and then a slight look of perplexity crossed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his face, and he continued, "I don't think I can."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Young people," said the Philosopher, "do not know what age is, and old
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: people forget what youth was. When you begin to grow old always think
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: deeply of your youth, for an old man without memories is a wasted life,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and nothing is worth remembering but our childhood. I will tell you some
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the differences between being old and young, and then you can ask me
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: questions, and so we will get at both sides of the matter. First, an old
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man gets tired quicker than a boy."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy thought for a moment, and then replied:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is not a great difference, for a boy does get very tired."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher continued:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "An old man does not want to eat as often as a boy."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is not a great difference either," the boy replied, "for they both
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: do eat. Tell me the big difference."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not know it, my son; but I have always thought there was a big
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: difference. Perhaps it is that an old man has memories of things which a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: boy cannot even guess at."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "But they both have memories," said the boy, laughing, "and so it is not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a big difference."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is true," said the Philosopher. "Maybe there is not so much
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: difference after all. Tell me things you do, and we will see if I can do
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: them also."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "But I don't know what I do," he replied.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You must know the things you do," said the Philosopher, "but you may
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not understand how to put them in order. The great trouble about any
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: kind of examination is to know where to begin, but there are always two
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: places in everything with which we can commence--they are the beginning
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the end. From either of these points a view may be had which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: comprehends the entire period. So we will begin with the things you did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this morning."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am satisfied with that," said the boy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher then continued:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "When you awakened this morning and went out of the house what was the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: first thing you did?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy thought "I went out, then I picked up a stone and threw it into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the field as far as I could."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What then?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Then I ran after the stone to see could I catch up on it before it hit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the ground."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Yes," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I ran so fast that I tumbled over myself into the grass."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What did you do after that?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I lay where I fell and plucked handfuls of the grass with both hands
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and threw them on my back."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Did you get up then?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, I pressed my face into the grass and shouted a lot of times with my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mouth against the ground, and then I sat up and did not move for a long
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Were you thinking?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "No, I was not thinking or doing anything."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why did you do all these things?" said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "For no reason at all," said the boy.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That," said the Philosopher triumphantly, "is the difference between
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: age and youth. Boys do things for no reason, and old people do not.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I wonder do we get old because we do things by reason instead of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instinct?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't know," said the boy, "everything gets old. Have you travelled
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: very far to-day, sir?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will tell you that if you will tell me your name."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "My name," said the boy, "is MacCushin."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "When I came last night," said the Philosopher, "from the place of Angus
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Og in the Caste of the Sleepers I was bidden say to one named MacCushin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that a son would be born to Angus Og and his wife, Caitilin, and that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the sleepers of Erinn had turned in their slumbers."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy regarded him steadfastly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I know," said he, "why Angus Og sent me that message. He wants me to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: make a poem to the people of Erinn, so that when the Sleepers arise they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: will meet with friends."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The Sleepers have arisen," said the Philosopher. "They are about us on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: every side. They are walking now, but they have forgotten their names
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the meanings of their names. You are to tell them their names and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their lineage, for I am an old man, and my work is done."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will make a poem some day," said the boy, "and every man will shout
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when he hears it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "God be with you, my son," said the Philosopher, and he embraced the boy
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and went forward on his journey.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: About half an hour's easy travelling brought him to a point from which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he could see far down below to the pine trees of Coille Doraca. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shadowy evening had crept over the world ere he reached the wood, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when he entered the little house the darkness had already descended.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman of Inis Magrath met him as he entered, and was about to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: speak harshly of his long absence, but the Philosopher kissed her with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: such unaccustomed tenderness, and spoke so mildly to her, that, first,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: astonishment enchained her tongue, and then delight set it free in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: direction to which it had long been a stranger.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Wife," said the Philosopher, "I cannot say how joyful I am to see your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good face again."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman was unable at first to reply to this salutation, but,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with incredible speed, she put on a pot of stirabout, began to bake a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cake, and tried to roast potatoes. After a little while she wept loudly,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and proclaimed that the world did not contain the equal of her husband
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for comeliness and goodness, and that she was herself a sinful person
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: unworthy of the kindness of the gods or of such a mate.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But while the Philosopher was embracing Seumas and Brigid Beg, the door
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was suddenly burst open with a great noise, four policemen entered the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: little room, and after one dumbfoundered minute they retreated again
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bearing the Philosopher with them to answer a charge of murder.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: BOOK V. THE POLICEMEN
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CHAPTER XIV
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: SOME distance down the road the policemen halted. The night had fallen
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: before they effected their capture, and now, in the gathering darkness,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they were not at ease. In the first place, they knew that the occupation
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: upon which they were employed was not a creditable one to a man whatever
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it might be to a policeman. The seizure of a criminal may be justified
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by certain arguments as to the health of society and the preservation
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of property, but no person wishes under any circumstances to hale a wise
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man to prison. They were further distressed by the knowledge that they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were in the very centre of a populous fairy country, and that on every
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: side the elemental hosts might be ranging, ready to fall upon them with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the terrors of war or the still more awful scourge of their humour.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The path leading to their station was a long one, winding through great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: alleys of trees, which in some places overhung the road so thickly that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: even the full moon could not search out that deep blackness. In the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: daylight these men would have arrested an Archangel and, if necessary,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bludgeoned him, but in the night-time a thousand fears afflicted and a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: multitude of sounds shocked them from every quarter.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Two men were holding the Philosopher, one on either side; the other two
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: walked one before and one behind him. In this order they were proceeding
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when just in front through the dim light they saw the road swallowed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: up by one of these groves already spoken of. When they came nigh they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: halted irresolutely: the man who was in front (a silent and perturbed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sergeant) turned fiercely to the others "Come on, can't you?" said he;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "what the devil are you waiting for?" and he strode forward into the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: black gape.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Keep a good hold of that man," said the one behind.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Don't be talking out of you," replied he on the right. "Haven't we got
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a good grip of him, and isn't he an old man into the bargain?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, keep a good tight grip of him, anyhow, for if he gave you the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: slip in there he'd vanish like a weasel in a bush. Them old fellows do
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be slippery customers. Look here, mister," said he to the Philosopher,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "if you try to run away from us I'll give you a clout on the head with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my baton; do you mind me now!"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They had taken only a few paces forward when the sound of hasty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: footsteps brought them again to a halt, and in a moment the sergeant
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: came striding back. He was angry.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Are you going to stay there the whole night, or what are you going to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: do at all?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Let you be quiet now," said another; "we were only settling with the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man here the way he wouldn't try to give us the slip in a dark place."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is it thinking of giving us the slip he is?" said the sergeant. "Take
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: your baton in your hand, Shawn, and if he turns his head to one side of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him hit him on that side."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll do that," said Shawn, and he pulled out his truncheon.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher had been dazed by the suddenness of these occurrences,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the enforced rapidity of his movements prevented him from either
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thinking or speaking, but during this brief stoppage his scattered
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wits began to return to their allegiance. First, bewilderment at his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: enforcement had seized him, and the four men, who were continually
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: running round him and speaking all at once, and each pulling him in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: different direction, gave him the impression that he was surrounded by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a great rabble of people, but he could not discover what they wanted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: After a time he found that there were only four men, and gathered from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their remarks that he was being arrested for murder--this precipitated
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him into another and a deeper gulf of bewilderment. He was unable to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conceive why they should arrest him for murder when he had not committed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: any; and, following this, he became indignant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not go another step," said he, "unless you tell me where you are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bringing me and what I am accused of."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Tell me," said the sergeant, "what did you kill them with? for it's a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: miracle how they came to their ends without as much as a mark on their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: skins or a broken tooth itself."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Who are you talking about?" the Philosopher demanded.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's mighty innocent you are," he replied. "Who would I be talking
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: about but the man and woman that used to be living with you beyond in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the little house? Is it poison you gave them now, or what was it? Take a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hold of your note-book, Shawn."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Can't you have sense, man?" said Shawn. "How would I be writing in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: middle of a dark place and me without as much as a pencil, let alone a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: book?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, we'll take it down at the station, and himself can tell us
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: all about it as we go along. Move on now, for this is no place to be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conversing in."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They paced on again, and in another moment they were swallowed up by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the darkness. When they had proceeded for a little distance there came a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peculiar sound in front like the breathing of some enormous animal, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: also a kind of shuffling noise, and so they again halted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's a queer kind of a thing in front of us," said one of the men in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a low voice.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If I had a match itself," said another.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The sergeant had also halted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Draw well into the side of the road," said he, "and poke your batons in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: front of you. Keep a tight hold of that man, Shawn."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll do that," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Just then one of them found a few matches in his pocket, and he struck a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: light; there was no wind, so that it blazed easily enough, and they all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peered in front. A big black cart-horse was lying in the middle of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: road having a gentle sleep, and when the light shone it scrambled to its
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: feet and went thundering away in a panic.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Isn't that enough to put the heart crossways in you?" said one of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: men, with a great sigh.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Ay," said another; "if you stepped on that beast in the darkness you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wouldn't know what to be thinking."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't quite remember the way about here," said the sergeant after a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: while, "but I think we should take the first turn to the right. I wonder
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have we passed the turn yet; these criss-cross kinds of roads are the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: devil, and it dark as well. Do any of you men know the way?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't," said one voice; "I'm a Cavan man myself."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Roscommon," said another, "is my country, and I wish I was there now,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: so I do."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, if we walk straight on we're bound to get somewhere, so step it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: out. Have you got a good hold of that man, Shawn?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have so," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher's voice came pealing through the darkness.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There is no need to pinch me, sir," said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'm not pinching you at all," said the man.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are so," returned the Philosopher. "You have a big lump of skin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: doubled up in the sleeve of my coat, and unless you instantly release it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I will sit down in the road."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is that any better?" said the man, relaxing his hold a little.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You have only let out half of it," replied the Philosopher. "That's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: better now," he continued, and they resumed their journey.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: After a few minutes of silence the Philosopher began to speak.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not see any necessity in nature for policemen," said he, "nor do I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: understand how the custom first originated. Dogs and cats do not employ
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these extraordinary mercenaries, and yet their polity is progressive
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and orderly. Crows are a gregarious race with settled habitations and an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: organized commonwealth. They usually congregate in a ruined tower or on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the top of a church, and their civilization is based on mutual aid and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tolerance for each other's idiosyncrasies. Their exceeding mobility and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hardiness renders them dangerous to attack, and thus they are free to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: devote themselves to the development of their domestic laws and customs.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: If policemen were necessary to a civilization crows would certainly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have evolved them, but I triumphantly insist that they have not got any
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: policemen in their republic--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I don't understand a word you are saying," said the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It doesn't matter," said the Philosopher. "Ants and bees also live in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: specialized communities and have an extreme complexity both of function
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and occupation. Their experience in governmental matters is enormous,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and yet they have never discovered that a police force is at all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: essential to their wellbeing--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you know," said the sergeant, "that whatever you say now will be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: used in evidence against you later on?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not," said the Philosopher. "It may be said that these races are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: free from crime, that such vices as they have are organized and communal
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instead of individual and anarchistic, and that, consequently, there
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is no necessity for policecraft, but I cannot believe that these large
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: aggregations of people could have attained their present high culture
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: without an interval of both national and individual dishonesty--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Tell me now, as you are talking," said the sergeant, "did you buy the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: poison at a chemist's shop, or did you smother the pair of them with a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pillow?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I did not," said the Philosopher. "If crime is a condition precedent to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the evolution of policemen, then I will submit that jackdaws are a very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thievish clan--they are somewhat larger than a blackbird, and will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: steal wool off a sheep's back to line their nests with; they have,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: furthermore, been known to abstract one shilling in copper and secrete
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this booty so ingeniously that it has never since been recovered--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I had a jackdaw myself," said one of the men. "I got it from a woman
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that came to the door with a basket for fourpence. My mother stood on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: its back one day, and she getting out of bed. I split its tongue with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a threepenny bit the way it would talk, but devil the word it ever said
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for me. It used to hop around letting on it had a lame leg, and then it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would steal your socks."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shut up!" roared the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If," said the Philosopher, "these people steal both from from sheep and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from men, if their peculations range from wool to money, I do not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: see how they can avoid stealing from each other, and consequently, if
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: anywhere, it is amongst jackdaws one should look for the growth of a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: police force, but there is no such force in existence. The real reason
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is that they are a witty and thoughtful race who look temperately on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: what is known as crime and evil--one eats, one steals; it is all in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: order of things, and therefore not to be quarrelled with. There is no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: other view possible to a philosophical people--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What the devil is he talking about?" said the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Monkeys are gregarious and thievish and semi-human. They inhabit the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: equatorial latitudes and eat nuts--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you know what he is saying, Shawn?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "--they ought to have evolved professional thief-takers, but it is common
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: knowledge that they have not done so. Fishes, squirrels, rats, beavers,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and bison have also abstained from this singular growth--therefore,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when I insist that I see no necessity for policemen and object to their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: presence, I base that objection on logic and facts, and not on any
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: immediate petty prejudice."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shawn," said the sergeant, "have you got a good grip on that man?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, if he talks any more hit him with your baton."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will so," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's a speck of light down yonder, and, maybe, it's a candle in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: window--we'll ask the way at that place."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In about three minutes they came to a small house which was overhung
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by trees. If the light had not been visible they would undoubtedly have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: passed it in the darkness. As they approached the door the sound of a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: female voice came to them scoldingly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There's somebody up anyhow," said the sergeant, and he tapped at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: door.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The scolding voice ceased instantly. After a few seconds he tapped
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again; then a voice was heard from just behind the door.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Tomas," said the voice, "go and bring up the two dogs with you before I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: take the door off the chain."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The door was then opened a few inches and a face peered out "What would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you be wanting at this hour of the night?" said the woman.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Not much, ma'am," said the sergeant; "only a little direction about the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: road, for we are not sure whether we've gone too far or not far enough."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The woman noticed their uniforms.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is it policemen ye are? There's no harm in your coming in, I suppose,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and if a drink of milk is any good to ye I have plenty of it."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Milk's better than nothing," said the sergeant with a sigh.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I've a little sup of spirits," said she, "but it wouldn't be enough to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: go around."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Ah, well," said he, looking sternly at his comrades, "everybody has to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: take their chance in this world," and he stepped into the house followed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by his men.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The women gave him a little sup of whisky from a bottle, and to each of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the other men she gave a cup of milk.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It'll wash the dust out of our gullets, anyhow," said one of them.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: There were two chairs, a bed, and a table in the room. The Philosopher
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and his attendants sat on the bed. The sergeant sat on the table,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the fourth man took a chair, and the woman dropped wearily into the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: remaining chair from which she looked with pity at the prisoner.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What are you taking the poor man away for?" she asked.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He's a bad one, ma'am," said the sergeant. "He killed a man and a woman
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that were staying with him and he buried their corpses underneath the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hearthstone of his house. He's a real malefactor, mind you."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is it hanging him you'll be, God help us?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You never know, and I wouldn't be a bit surprised if it came to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that. But you were in trouble yourself, ma'am, for we heard your voice
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lamenting about something as we came along the road."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I was, indeed," she replied, "for the person that has a son in her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: house has a trouble in her heart."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Do you tell me now--What did he do on you?" and the sergeant bent a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: look of grave reprobation on a young lad who was standing against the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wall between two dogs.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He's a good boy enough in some ways," said she, "but he's too fond
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of beasts. He'll go and lie in the kennel along with them two dogs for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hours at a time, petting them and making a lot of them, but if I try
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to give him a kiss, or to hug him for a couple of minutes when I do be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tired after the work, he'll wriggle like an eel till I let him out--it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would make a body hate him, so it would. Sure, there's no nature in him,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sir, and I'm his mother."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You ought to be ashamed of yourself, you young whelp," said the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sergeant very severely.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "And then there's the horse," she continued. "Maybe you met it down the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: road a while ago?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We did, ma'am," said the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Well, when he came in Tomas went to tie him up, for he's a caution at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: getting out and wandering about the road, the way you'd break your neck
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: over him if you weren't minding. After a while I told the boy to come
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in, but he didn't come, so I went out myself, and there was himself and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the horse with their arms round each other's necks looking as if they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were moonstruck."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Faith, he's the queer lad!" said the sergeant. "What do you be making
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: love to the horse for, Tomas?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It was all I could do to make him come in," she continued, "and then I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: said to him, 'Sit down alongside of me here, Tomas, and keep me company
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for a little while'--for I do be lonely in the night-time--but he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wouldn't stay quiet at all. One minute he'd say, 'Mother, there's a moth
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: flying round the candle and it'll be burnt,' and then, 'There was a fly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: going into the spider's web in the corner,' and he'd have to save
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it, and after that, 'There's a daddy-long-legs hurting himself on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: window-pane,' and he'd have to let it out; but when I try to kiss him he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pushes me away. My heart is tormented, so it is, for what have I in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: world but him?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is his father dead, ma'am?" said the sergeant kindly.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'll tell the truth," said she. "I don't know whether he is or not, for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a long time ago, when we used to live in the city of Bla' Cliah, he lost
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his work one time and he never came back to me again. He was ashamed to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: come home I'm thinking, the poor man, because he had no money; as if
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I would have minded whether he had any money or not--sure, he was very
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fond of me, sir, and we could have pulled along somehow. After that I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: came back to my father's place here; the rest of the children died on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: me, and then my father died, and I'm doing the best I can by myself.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It's only that I'm a little bit troubled with the boy now and again."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's a hard case, ma'am," said the sergeant, "but maybe the boy is only
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a bit wild not having his father over him, and maybe it's just that he's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: used to yourself, for there isn't a child at all that doesn't love his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mother. Let you behave yourself now, Tomas; attend to your mother, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leave the beasts and the insects alone, like a decent boy, for there's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: no insect in the world will ever like you as well as she does. Could you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tell me, ma'am, if we have passed the first turn on this road, or is it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in front of us still, for we are lost altogether in the darkness?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It's in front of you still," she replied, "about ten minutes down the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: road; you can't miss it, for you'll see the sky where there is a gap in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the trees, and that gap is the turn you want."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Thank you, ma'am," said the sergeant; "we'd better be moving on, for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there's a long tramp in front of us before we get to sleep this night."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He stood up and the men rose to follow him when, suddenly, the boy spoke
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in a whisper.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Mother," said he, "they are going to hang the man," and he burst into
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tears.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Oh, hush, hush," said the woman, "sure, the men can't help it." She
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: dropped quickly on her knees and opened her arms, "Come over to your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: mother, my darling."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy ran to her.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "They are going to hang him," he cried in a high, thin voice, and he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: plucked at her arm violently.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Now, then, my young boy-o," said the sergeant, "none of that violence."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The boy turned suddenly and flew at him with astonishing ferocity. He
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hurled himself against the sergeant's legs and bit, and kicked, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: struck at him. So furiously sudden was his attack that the man went
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: staggering back against the wall, then he plucked at the boy and whirled
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him across the room. In an instant the two dogs leaped at him snarling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with rage--one of these he kicked into a corner, from which it rebounded
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again bristling and red-eyed; the other dog was caught by the woman,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and after a few frantic seconds she gripped the first dog also. To a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: horrible chorus of howls and snapping teeth the men hustled outside and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: slammed the door.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shawn," the sergeant bawled, "have you got a good grip of that man?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have so," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If he gets away I'll kick the belly out of you; mind that now! Come
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: along with you and no more of your slouching."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: They marched down the road in a tingling silence.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Dogs," said the Philosopher, "are a most intelligent race of people--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "People, my granny!" said the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "From the earliest ages their intelligence has been observed and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: recorded, so that ancient literatures are bulky with references to their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sagacity and fidelity--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Will you shut your old jaw?" said the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not," said the Philosopher. "Elephants also are credited with an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: extreme intelligence and devotion to their masters, and they will build
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a wall or nurse a baby with equal skill and happiness. Horses have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: received high recommendations in this respect, but crocodiles, hens,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beetles, armadillos, and fish do not evince any remarkable partiality
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for man--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I wish," said the sergeant bitterly, "that all them beasts were stuffed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: down your throttle the way you'd have to hold your prate."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "It doesn't matter," said the Philosopher. "I do not know why these
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: animals should attach themselves to men with gentleness and love and yet
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be able to preserve intact their initial bloodthirstiness, so that while
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they will allow their masters to misuse them in any way they will yet
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: fight most willingly with each other, and are never really happy saving
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in the conduct of some private and nonsensical battle of their own. I do
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not believe that it is fear which tames these creatures into mildness,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but that the most savage animal has a capacity for love which has not
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: been sufficiently noted, and which, if more intelligent attention
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: had been directed upon it, would have raised them to the status of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: intellectual animals as against intelligent ones, and, perhaps, have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: opened to us a correspondence which could not have been other than
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beneficial."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Keep your eyes out for that gap in the trees, Shawn," said the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'm doing that," said Shawn.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher continued:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why can I not exchange ideas with a cow? I am amazed at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: incompleteness of my growth when I and a fellow-creature stand dumbly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: before each other without one glimmer of comprehension, locked and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: barred from all friendship and intercourse--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shawn," cried the sergeant.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Don't interrupt," said the Philosopher; "you are always talking.--The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lower animals, as they are foolishly called, have abilities at which we
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: can only wonder. The mind of an ant is one to which I would readily go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to school. Birds have atmospheric and levitational information which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: millions of years will not render accessible to us; who that has seen a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: spider weaving his labyrinth, or a bee voyaging safely in the trackless
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: air, can refuse to credit that a vivid, trained intelligence animates
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: these small enigmas? and the commonest earthworm is the heir to a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: culture before which I bow with the profoundest veneration--"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Shawn," said the sergeant, "say something for goodness' sake to take
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the sound of that man's clack out of my ear."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I wouldn't know what to be talking about," said Shawn, "for I never
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was much of a hand at conversation, and, barring my prayers, I got no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: education--I think myself that he was making a remark about a dog. Did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you ever own a dog, sergeant?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are doing very well, Shawn," said the sergeant, "keep it up now."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I knew a man had a dog would count up to a hundred for you. He won lots
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of money in bets about it, and he'd have made a fortune, only that I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: noticed one day he used to be winking at the dog, and when he'd stop
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: winking the dog would stop counting. We made him turn his back after
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that, and got the dog to count sixpence, but he barked for more than
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: five shillings, he did so, and he would have counted up to a pound,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: maybe, only that his master turned round and hit him a kick. Every
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: person that ever paid him a bet said they wanted their money back, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the man went away to America in the night, and I expect he's doing well
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there for he took the dog with him. It was a wire-haired terrier bitch,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and it was the devil for having pups."
title: The Crock of Gold

text: Coille Doraca for a long time, to be sure; for isn't it true that if

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

text: here and there--but this time, decent men of the Gort, I cannot go with

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I think, that a man should always obey the law with his body and always
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

text: CHAPTER XVI
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: WHEN he knocked at the barracks door it was opened by a man with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tousled, red hair, who looked as though he had just awakened from sleep.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "What do you want at this hour of the night?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I want to give myself up," said the Philosopher. The policeman looked
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: at him "A man as old as you are," said he, "oughtn't to be a fool. Go
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: home now, I advise you, and don't say a word to any one whether you did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it or not. Tell me this now, was it found out, or are you only making a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: clean breast of it?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Sure I must give myself up," said the Philosopher.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If you must, you must, and that's an end of it. Wipe your feet on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rail there and come in--I'll take your deposition."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I have no deposition for you," said the Philosopher, "for I didn't do a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing at all."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The policeman stared at him again.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If that's so," said he, "you needn't come in at all, and you needn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have wakened me out of my sleep either. Maybe, tho', you are the man
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that fought the badger on the Naas Road--Eh?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am not," replied the Philosopher: "but I was arrested for killing my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brother and his wife, although I never touched them."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Is that who you are?" said the policeman; and then, briskly, "You're as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: welcome as the cuckoo, you are so. Come in and make yourself comfortable
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: till the men awaken, and they are the lads that'll be glad to see you.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I couldn't make head or tail of what they said when they came in last
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: night, and no one else either, for they did nothing but fight each other
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and curse the banshees and cluricauns of Leinster. Sit down there on the
title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

text: boots."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher thanked him and stretched out on the settle. In a short
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time, for he was very weary, he fell asleep.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rising, that the men who had captured him on the previous evening were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: only in his trousers and shirt. His hair was sticking up in some places
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and sticking out in others which gave a certain wild look to him, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his feet were bare. He took the Philosopher's two hands in his own and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: swore if ever there was anything he could do to comfort him he would do

author: Stephens, James

text: that and more. Shawn, in a similar state of unclothedness, greeted the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Philosopher and proclaimed himself his friend and follower for ever.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: killed the two people, that if he had killed them they must have richly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: deserved it, and that if he was hung he would plant flowers on his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grave; for a decenter, quieter, and wiser man he had never met and never

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: These professions of esteem comforted the Philosopher, and he replied to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and approval.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He was given a breakfast of bread and cocoa which he ate with his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: guardians, and then, as they had to take up their outdoor duties, he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and that he might smoke until he was black in the face. The policemen
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: devices.
title: The Crock of Gold

text: The garden was about twelve feet square, having high, smooth walls on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: every side, and into it there came neither sun nor wind. In one corner a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: clump of rusty-looking sweet-pea was climbing up the wall--every leaf
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of this plant was riddled with holes, and there were no flowers on it.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Another corner was occupied by dwarf nasturtiums, and on this plant,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in despite of every discouragement, two flowers were blooming, but its
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leaves also were tattered and dejected. A mass of ivy clung to the third
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: corner, its leaves were big and glossy at the top, but near the ground
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: there was only grey, naked stalks laced together by cobwebs. The fourth
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wall was clothed in a loose Virginia creeper every leaf of which looked
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: like an insect that could crawl if it wanted to. The centre of this
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: small plot had used every possible artifice to cover itself with grass,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and in some places it had wonderfully succeeded, but the pieces of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: broken bottles, shattered jampots, and sections of crockery were so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: numerous that no attempt at growth could be other than tentative and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: unpassioned.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Here, for a long time, the Philosopher marched up and down. At one
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: moment he examined the sweet-pea and mourned with it on a wretched
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: existence. Again he congratulated the nasturtium on its two bright
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children; but he thought of the gardens wherein they might have bloomed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the remembrance of that spacious, sunny freedom saddened him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Indeed, poor creatures!" said he, "ye also are in gaol."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The blank, soundless yard troubled him so much that at last he called to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the red-haired policeman and begged to be put into a cell in preference;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and to the common cell he was, accordingly, conducted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: This place was a small cellar built beneath the level of the ground. An
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: iron grating at the top of the wall admitted one blanched wink of light,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but the place was bathed in obscurity. A wooden ladder led down to the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cell from a hole in the ceiling, and this hole also gave a spark of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brightness and some little air to the room. The walls were of stone
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: covered with plaster, but the plaster had fallen away in many places
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leaving the rough stones visible at every turn of the eye.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: There were two men in the cell, and these the Philosopher saluted; but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they did not reply, nor did they speak to each other. There was a low,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wooden form fixed to the wall, running quite round the room, and on
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this, far apart from each other, the two men were seated, with their
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: elbows resting on their knees, their heads propped upon their hands,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and each of them with an unwavering gaze fixed on the floor between his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: feet.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Philosopher walked for a time up and down the little cell, but soon
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he also sat down on the low form, propped his head on his hands and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: lapsed to a melancholy dream.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So the day passed. Twice a policeman came down the ladder bearing three
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: portions of food, bread and cocoa; and by imperceptible gradations the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: light faded away from the grating and the darkness came. After a great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: interval the policeman again approached carrying three mattresses and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: three rough blankets, and these he bundled through the hole. Each of the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: men took a mattress and a blanket and spread them on the floor, and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Philosopher took his share also.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: By this time they could not see each other and all their operations were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conducted by the sense of touch alone. They laid themselves down on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beds and a terrible, dark silence brooded over the room.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But the Philosopher could not sleep, he kept his eyes shut, for the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: darkness under his eyelids was not so dense as that which surrounded
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him; indeed, he could at will illuminate his own darkness and order
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: around him the sunny roads or the sparkling sky. While his eyes were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: closed he had the mastery of all pictures of light and colour and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: warmth, but an irresistible fascination compelled him every few minutes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to reopen them, and in the sad space around he could not create any
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: happiness. The darkness weighed very sadly upon him so that in a short
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time it did creep under his eyelids and drowned his happy pictures until
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a blackness possessed him both within and without "Can one's mind go to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: prison as well as one's body?" said he.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He strove desperately to regain his intellectual freedom, but he could
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not. He could conjure up no visions but those of fear. The creatures of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the dark invaded him, fantastic terrors were thronging on every side:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they came from the darkness into his eyes and beyond into himself, so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that his mind as well as his fancy was captured, and he knew he was,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: indeed, in gaol.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It was with a great start that he heard a voice speaking from the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: silence--a harsh, yet cultivated voice, but he could not imagine which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of his companions was speaking. He had a vision of that man tormented
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by the mental imprisonment of the darkness, trying to get away from his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ghosts and slimy enemies, goaded into speech in his own despite lest he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: should be submerged and finally possessed by the abysmal demons. For a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: while the voice spoke of the strangeness of life and the cruelty of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: men to each other--disconnected sentences, odd words of selfpity and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: self-encouragement, and then the matter became more connected and a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: story grew in the dark cell "I knew a man," said the voice, "and he was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a clerk. He had thirty shillings a week, and for five years he had never
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: missed a day going to his work. He was a careful man, but a person with
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a wife and four children cannot save much out of thirty shillings a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: week. The rent of a house is high, a wife and children must be fed, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they have to get boots and clothes, so that at the end of each week
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that man's thirty shillings used to be all gone. But they managed to get
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: along somehow--the man and his wife and the four children were fed and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: clothed and educated, and the man often wondered how so much could
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be done with so little money; but the reason was that his wife was a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to get sick, and a married man cannot leave his work. If he is sick
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: he has to be sick; but he must go to his work all the same, for if he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stayed away who would pay the wages and feed his family? and when he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went back to work he might find that there was nothing for him to do.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: what was wrong with him: he only knew that he was sick. Sometimes he had
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sharp, swift pains in his head, and again there would be long hours of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

text: the up and down strokes, and being troubled when he had to leave that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: would start on the third with hatred. The end of a word seemed to that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man like the conclusion of an event--it was a surprising, isolated,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: individual thing, having no reference to anything else in the world,

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on rusty hinges that could scarcely move. Each hour was like a great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: circle swollen with heavy air, and it droned and buzzed into an

author: Stephens, James
