text: slipped. There was an instinct in him somewhere not to let the pen
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: slip, and every time the pen moved his hand awakened, and began to work
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: languidly. When he went home at night he lay down at once and stared
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for hours at a fly on the wall or a crack on the ceiling. When his wife
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: spoke to him he heard her speaking as from a great distance, and he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: answered her dully as though he was replying through a cloud. He only
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wanted to be let alone, to be allowed to stare at the fly on the wall,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or the crack on the ceiling.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "One morning he found that he couldn't get up, or rather, that he didn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: want to get up. When his wife called him he made no reply, and she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: seemed to call him every ten seconds--the words, 'get up, get up,' were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: crackling all round him; they were bursting like bombs on the right hand
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and on the left of him: they were scattering from above and all around
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him, bursting upwards from the floor, swirling, swaying, and jostling
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: each other. Then the sounds ceased, and one voice only said to him
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: 'You are late!' He saw these words like a blur hanging in the air, just
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beyond his eyelids, and he stared at the blur until he fell asleep."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The voice in the cell ceased speaking for a few minutes, and then it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went on again.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "For three weeks the man did not leave his bed--he lived faintly in a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: kind of trance, wherein great forms moved about slowly and immense
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: words were drumming gently for ever. When he began to take notice again
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: everything in the house was different. Most of the furniture, paid for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: so hardly, was gone. He missed a thing everywhere--chairs, a mirror,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a table: wherever he looked he missed something; and downstairs was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: worse--there, everything was gone. His wife had sold all her furniture
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to pay for doctors, for medicine, for food and rent. And she was changed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: too: good things had gone from her face; she was gaunt, sharp-featured,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: miserable--but she was comforted to think he was going back to work
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: soon.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There was a flurry in his head when he went to his office. He didn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: know what his employer would say for stopping away. He might blame him
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for being sick--he wondered would his employer pay him for the weeks he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was absent. When he stood at the door he was frightened. Suddenly the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thought of his master's eye grew terrible to him: it was a steady, cold,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: glassy eye; but he opened the door and went in. His master was there
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: with another man and he tried to say 'Good morning, sir,' in a natural
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and calm voice; but he knew that the strange man had been engaged
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: instead of himself, and this knowledge posted itself between his tongue
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and his thought. He heard himself stammering, he felt that his whole
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bearing had become drooping and abject. His master was talking swiftly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and the other man was looking at him in an embarrassed, stealthy, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pleading manner: his eyes seemed to be apologising for having supplanted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him--so he mumbled 'Good day, sir,' and stumbled out.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "When he got outside he could not think where to go. After a while he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went in the direction of the little park in the centre of the city. It
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was quite near and he sat down on an iron bench facing a pond. There
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: were children walking up and down by the water giving pieces of bread to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the swans. Now and again a labouring man or a messenger went by quickly;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: now and again a middleaged, slovenly-dressed man drooped past aimlessly:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sometimes a tattered, self-intent woman with a badgered face flopped by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: him. When he looked at these dull people the thought came to him that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they were not walking there at all; they were trailing through hell,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and their desperate eyes saw none but devils around them. He saw himself
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: joining these battered strollers... and he could not think what he would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tell his wife when he went home. He rehearsed to himself the terms of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his dismissal a hundred times. How his master looked, what he had said:
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and then the fine, ironical things he had said to his master. He sat in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the park all day, and when evening fell he went home at his accustomed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hour.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "His wife asked him questions as to how he had got on, and wanted to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: know was there any chance of being paid for the weeks of absence; the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: man answered her volubly, ate his supper and went to bed: but he did
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not tell his wife that he had been dismissed and that there would be no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: money at the end of the week. He tried to tell her, but when he met her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eye he found that he could not say the words--he was afraid of the look
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that might come into her face when she heard it--she, standing terrified
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in those dismantled rooms...!
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "In the morning he ate his breakfast and went out again--to work, his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: wife thought. She bid him ask the master about the three weeks' wages,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or to try and get an advance on the present week's wages, for they were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: hardly put to it to buy food. He said he would do his best, but he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: went straight to the park and sat looking at the pond, looking at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: passers-by and dreaming. In the middle of the day he started up in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a panic and went about the city asking for work in offices, shops,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: warehouses, everywhere, but he could not get any. He trailed back
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: heavy-footed again to the park and sat down.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He told his wife more lies about his work that night and what his
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: master had said when he asked for an advance. He couldn't bear the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children to touch him. After a little time he sneaked away to his bed.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "A week went that way. He didn't look for work any more. He sat in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: park, dreaming, with his head bowed into his hands. The next day would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be the day he should have been paid his wages. The next day! What would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: his wife say when he told her he had no money? She would stare at him
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and flush and say-'Didn't you go out every day to work?'--How would he
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tell her then so that she could understand quickly and spare him words?
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Morning came and the man ate his breakfast silently. There was no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: butter on the bread, and his wife seemed to be apologising to him for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not having any. She said, 'We'll be able to start fair from to-morrow,'
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and when he snapped at her angrily she thought it was because he had to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eat dry bread.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "He went to the park and sat there for hours. Now and again he got up
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and walked into a neighbouring street, but always, after half an hour
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or so, he came back. Six o'clock in the evening was his hour for going
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: home. When six o'clock came he did not move, he still sat opposite the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pond with his head bowed down into his arms. Seven o'clock passed. At
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nine o'clock a bell was rung and every one had to leave. He went also.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He stood outside the gates looking on this side and on that. Which
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: way would he go? All roads were alike to him, so he turned at last and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: walked somewhere. He did not go home that night. He never went home
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: again. He never was heard of again anywhere in the wide world."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The voice ceased speaking and silence swung down again upon the little
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cell. The Philosopher had been listening intently to this story, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: after a few minutes he spoke "When you go up this road there is a turn
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to the left and all the path along is bordered with trees--there are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: birds in the trees, Glory be to God! There is only one house on that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: road, and the woman in it gave us milk to drink. She has but one son, a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good boy, and she said the other children were dead; she was speaking of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a husband who went away and left her--'Why should he have been afraid to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: come home?' said she--'sure, I loved him.'"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: After a little interval the voice spoke again "I don't know what became
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the man I was speaking of. I am a thief, and I'm well known to the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: police everywhere. I don't think that man would get a welcome at the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: house up here, for why should he?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Another, a different, querulous kind of voice came from the silence "If
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I knew a place where there was a welcome I'd go there as quickly as I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: could, but I don't know a place and I never will, for what good would
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a man of my age be to any person? I am a thief also. The first thing I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stole was a hen out of a little yard. I roasted it in a ditch and ate
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it, and then I stole another one and ate it, and after that I stole
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: everything I could lay my hands on. I suppose I will steal as long as I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: live, and I'll die in a ditch at the heel of the hunt. There was a time,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not long ago, and if any one had told me then that I would rob, even
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for hunger, I'd have been insulted: but what does it matter now? And
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the reason I am a thief is because I got old without noticing it.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Other people noticed it, but I did not. I suppose age comes on one so
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gradually that it is seldom observed. If there are wrinkles on one's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: face we do not remember when they were not there: we put down all kind
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of little infirmities to sedentary living, and you will see plenty of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: young people bald. If a man has no occasion to tell any one his age,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and if he never thinks of it himself, he won't see ten years' difference
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: between his youth and his age, for we live in slow, quiet times, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nothing ever happens to mark the years as they go by, one after the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: other, and all the same.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I lodged in a house for a great many years, and a little girl grew
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: up there, the daughter of my landlady. She used to slide down the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bannisters very well, and she used to play the piano very badly. These
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: two things worried me many a time. She used to bring me my meals in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: morning and the evening, and often enough she'd stop to talk with me
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: while I was eating. She was a very chatty girl and I was a talkative
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: person myself. When she was about eighteen years of age I got so used
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to her that if her mother came with the food I would be worried for
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the rest of the day. Her face was as bright as a sunbeam, and her lazy,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: careless ways, big, free movements, and girlish chatter were pleasant to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: a man whose loneliness was only beginning to be apparent to him through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her company. I've thought of it often since, and I suppose that's how it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: began. She used to listen to all my opinions and she'd agree with them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: because she had none of her own yet. She was a good girl, but lazy in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her mind and body; childish, in fact. Her talk was as involved as her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: actions: she always seemed to be sliding down mental bannisters; she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thought in kinks and spoke in spasms, hopped mentally from one subject
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to another without the slightest difficulty, and could use a lot of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: language in saying nothing at all. I could see all that at the time, but
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I suppose I was too pleased with my own sharp business brains, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sick enough, although I did not know it, of my sharp-brained, business
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: companions--dear Lord! I remember them well. It's easy enough to have
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: brains as they call it, but it is not so easy to have a little gaiety
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or carelessness or childishness or whatever it was she had. It is good,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: too, to feel superior to some one, even a girl.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "One day this thought came to me--'It is time that I settled down.' I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: don't know where the idea came from; one hears it often enough and it
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: always seems to apply to some one else, but I don't know what brought
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: it to roost with me. I was foolish, too: I bought ties and differently
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shaped collars, and took to creasing my trousers by folding them under
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the bed and lying on them all night--It never struck me that I was more
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: than three times her age. I brought home sweets for her and she was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: delighted. She said she adored sweets, and she used to insist on my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eating some of them with her; she liked to compare notes as to how they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tasted while eating them. I used to get a toothache from them, but I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bore with it although at that time I hated toothache almost as much as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I hated sweets. Then I asked her to come out with me for a walk. She
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was willing enough and it was a novel experience for me. Indeed, it was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rather exciting. We went out together often after that, and sometimes
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: we'd meet people I knew, young men from my office or from other offices.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I used to be shy when some of these people winked at me as they saluted.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It was pleasant, too, telling the girl who they were, their business and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their salaries: for there was little I didn't know. I used to tell her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of my own position in the office and what the chief said to me through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the day. Sometimes we talked of the things that had appeared in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: evening papers. A murder perhaps, some phase of a divorce case, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: speech a political person had made, or the price of stock. She was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: interested in anything so long as it was talk. And her own share in the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: conversation was good to hear. Every lady that passed us had a hat that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stirred her to the top of rapture or the other pinnacle of disgust.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: She told me what ladies were frights and what were ducks. Under her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: scampering tongue I began to learn something of humanity, even though
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she saw most people as delightfully funny clowns or superb, majestical
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: princes, but I noticed that she never said a bad word of a man, although
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: many of the men she looked after were ordinary enough. Until I went
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: walking with her I never knew what a shop window was. A jeweller's
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: window especially: there were curious things in it. She told me how a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: tiara should be worn, and a pendant, and she explained the kind of studs
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: I should wear myself; they were made of gold and had red stones in them;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she showed me the ropes of pearl or diamonds that she thought would look
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: pretty on herself: and one day she said that she liked me very much. I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was pleased and excited that day, but I was a business man and I said
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: very little in reply. I never liked a pig in a poke.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "She used to go out two nights in the week, Monday and Thursday, dressed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in her best clothes. I didn't know where she went, and I didn't ask--I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thought she visited an acquaintance, a girl friend or some such. The
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: time went by and I made up my mind to ask her to marry me. I had watched
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her long enough and she was always kind and bright. I liked the way she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: smiled, and I liked her obedient, mannerly bearing. There was something
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: else I liked, which I did not recognise then, something surrounding all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her movements, a graciousness, a spaciousness: I did not analyse it;
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but I know now that it was her youth. I remember that when we were out
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: together she walked slowly, but in the house she would leap up and down
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the stairs--she moved furiously, but I didn't.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "One evening she dressed to go out as usual, and she called at my door
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to know had I everything I wanted. I said I had something to tell her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: when she came home, something important. She promised to come in early
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to hear it, and I laughed at her and she laughed back and went sliding
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: down the bannisters. I don't think I have had any reason to laugh since
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that night. A letter came for me after she had gone, and I knew by the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: shape and the handwriting that it was from the office. It puzzled me to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: think why I should be written to. I didn't like opening it somehow....
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: It was my dismissal on account of advancing age, and it hoped for my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: future welfare politely enough. It was signed by the Senior. I didn't
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: grip it at first, and then I thought it was a hoax. For a long time I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sat in my room with an empty mind. I was watching my mind: there were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: immense distances in it that drowsed and buzzed; large, soft movements
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: seemed to be made in my mind, and although I was looking at the letter
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in my hand I was really trying to focus those great, swinging spaces in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: my brain, and my ears were listening for a movement of some kind. I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: can see back to that time plainly. I went walking up and down the room.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: There was a dull, subterranean anger in me. I remember muttering once or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: twice, 'Shameful!' and again I said, 'Ridiculous!' At the idea of age

text: THE ability of the Thin Woman of Inis Magrath for anger was unbounded.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: She was not one of those limited creatures who are swept clean by a gust
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of wrath and left placid and smiling after its passing. She could store
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: her anger in those caverns of eternity which open into every soul, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which are filled with rage and violence until the time comes when they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: may be stored with wisdom and love; for, in the genesis of life, love
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is at the beginning and the end of things. First, like a laughing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: child, love came to labour minutely in the rocks and sands of the heart,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

text: "Do you ever talk more than two words at the one time, ma'am?" said the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stranger.

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I'd give a penny to hear you," replied the other angrily, "for a more
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: bad-natured, cross-grained, cantankerous person than yourself I never
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: met among womankind. It's what I said to a man only yesterday, that thin
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ones are bad ones, and there isn't any one could be thinner than you are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: yourself."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "The reason you say that," said the Thin Woman calmly, "is because you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: are fat and you have to tell lies to yourself to hide your misfortune,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and let on that you like it. There is no one in the world could like to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be fat, and there I leave you, ma'am. You can poke your finger in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: your own eye, but you may keep it out of mine if you please, and, so,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: good-bye to you; and if I wasn't a quiet woman I'd pull you by the hair
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: of the head up a hill and down a hill for two hours, and now there's an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: end of it. I've given you more than two words; let you take care or I'll
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: give you two more that will put blisters on your body for ever. Come
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: along with me now, children, and if ever you see a woman like that woman
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: you'll know that she eats until she can't stand, and drinks until she
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: can't sit, and sleeps until she is stupid; and if that sort of person
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ever talks to you remember that two words are all that's due to her, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: let them be short ones, for a woman like that would be a traitor and a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thief, only that she's too lazy to be anything but a sot, God help her I
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and, so, good-bye."

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stranger they went down the wide path; but the other woman stayed where
title: The Crock of Gold

text: she was sitting, and she did not say a word even to herself.

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from her; so, after a while, they ceased to consider her at all and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: addressed themselves to their play. They danced before and behind
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and around her. They ran and doubled, shouted and laughed and sang.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rye. Sometimes one was a horse and the other was a driver, and then
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they stamped along the road with loud, fierce snortings and louder and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: journey, and he stopped to rest himself on the cow's nose.

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: stop for a talk. You've rather a good kind of life, I suppose, flying
title: The Crock of Gold

text: about and enjoying yourself."

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the sun to the dark exile of midnight. It is strange that we may not be

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sadness. Beauty has no liking for Thought, but will send terror and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sorrow on those who look upon her with intelligent eyes. We may neither
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be angry nor gay in the presence of the moon, nor may we dare to think
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in her bailiwick, or the Jealous One will surely afflict us. I think
title: The Crock of Gold

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

author: Stephens, James

text: "I do not know that," said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We are the Three Absolutes, the Three Redeemers, the three
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Alembics--the Most Beautiful Man, the Strongest Man and the Ugliest Man.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In the midst of every strife we go unhurt. We count the slain and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: victors and pass on laughing, and to us in the eternal order come all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the peoples of the world to be regenerated for ever. Why have you called
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to us?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I did not call to you, indeed," said the Thin Woman; "but why do you
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sit in the path so that travellers to the House of the Dagda are halted
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on their journey?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There are no paths closed to us," he replied; "even the gods seek us,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: for they grow weary in their splendid desolation--saving Him who liveth
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: in all things and in us; Him we serve and before His awful front we
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: abase ourselves. You, O Woman, who are walking in the valleys of anger,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have called to us in your heart, therefore we are waiting for you on the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: side of the hill. Choose now one of us to be your mate, and do not fear
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to choose, for our kingdoms are equal and our powers are equal."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Why would I choose one of you," replied the Thin Woman, "when I am well
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: married already to the best man in the world?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Beyond us there is no best man," said he, "for we are the best in
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: beauty, and the best in strength, and the best in ugliness; there is no
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: excellence which is not contained in us three. If you are married what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: does that matter to us who are free from the pettiness of jealousy
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and fear, being at one with ourselves and with every manifestation of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: nature."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "If," she replied, "you are the Absolute and are above all pettiness,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: can you not be superior to me also and let me pass quietly on my road to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Dagda!"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "We are what all humanity desire," quoth he, "and we desire all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: humanity. There is nothing, small or great, disdained by our immortal
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: appetites. It is not lawful, even for the Absolute, to outgrow Desire,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which is the breath of God quick in his creatures and not to be bounded
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: or surmounted by any perfection."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: During this conversation the other great figures had leaned forward
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: listening intently but saying nothing. The Thin Woman could feel the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children like little, terrified birds pressing closely and very quietly
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to her sides.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Sir," said she, "tell me what is Beauty and what is Strength and what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is Ugliness? for, although I can see these things, I do not know what
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: they are."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will tell you that," he replied--"Beauty is Thought and Strength is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Love and Ugliness is Generation. The home of Beauty is the head of man.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The home of Strength is the heart of man, and in the loins Ugliness
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: keeps his dreadful state. If you come with me you shall know all
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: delight. You shall live unharmed in the flame of the spirit, and nothing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that is gross shall bind your limbs or hinder your thought. You shall
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: move as a queen amongst all raging passions without torment or despair.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Never shall you be driven or ashamed, but always you will choose your
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: own paths and walk with me in freedom and contentment and beauty."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "All things," said the Thin Woman, "must act according to the order of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their being, and so I say to Thought, if you hold me against my will
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: presently I will bind you against your will, for the holder of an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: unwilling mate becomes the guardian and the slave of his captive."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "That is true," said he, "and against a thing that is true I cannot
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: contend; therefore, you are free from me, but from my brethren you are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not free."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman turned to the second man.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are Strength?" said she.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I am Strength and Love," he boomed, "and with me there is safety and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: peace; my days have honour and my nights quietness. There is no evil
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: thing walks near my lands, nor is any sound heard but the lowing of my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cattle, the songs of my birds and the laughter of my happy children.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Come then to me who gives protection and happiness and peace, and does
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not fail or grow weary at any time."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "I will not go with you," said the Thin Woman, "for I am a mother and my
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: strength cannot be increased; I am a mother and my love cannot be added
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to. What have I further to desire from thee, thou great man?"
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are free of me," said the second man, "but from my brother you are
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not free."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Then to the third man the Thin Woman addressed herself in terror, for to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that hideous one something cringed within her in an ecstasy of loathing.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: That repulsion which at its strongest becomes attraction gripped her.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: A shiver, a plunge, and she had gone, but the hands of the children
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: withheld her while in woe she abased herself before him.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: He spoke, and his voice came clogged and painful as though it urged from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the matted pores of the earth itself.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "There is none left to whom you may go but me only. Do not be afraid,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: but come to me and I will give you these wild delights which have been
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: long forgotten. All things which are crude and riotous, all that is
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: gross and without limit is mine. You shall not think and suffer any
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: longer; but you shall feel so surely that the heat of the sun will be
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: happiness: the taste of food, the wind that blows upon you, the ripe
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: ease of your body--these things will amaze you who have forgotten them.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: My great arms about you will make you furious and young again; you shall
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: leap on the hillside like a young goat and sing for joy as the birds
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sing. Leave this crabbed humanity that is barred and chained away
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: from joy and come with me, to whose ancient quietude at the last both
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Strength and Beauty will come like children tired in the evening,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: returning to the freedom of the brutes and the birds, with bodies
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sufficient for their pleasure and with no care for Thought or foolish
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: curiosity."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: But the Thin Woman drew back from his hand, saying "It is not lawful to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: turn again when the journey is commenced, but to go forward to whatever
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: is appointed; nor may we return to your meadows and trees and sunny
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: places who have once departed from them. The torments of the mind may
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: not be renounced for any easement of the body until the smoke that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: blinds us is blown away, and the tormenting flame has fitted us for that
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: immortal ecstasy which is the bosom of God. Nor is it lawful that ye
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: great ones should beset the path of travellers, seeking to lure them
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: away with cunning promises. It is only at the cross-roads ye may sit
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: where the traveller will hesitate and be in doubt, but on the highway ye
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: have no power."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "You are free of me," said the third man, "until you are ready to come
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to me again, for I only of all things am steadfast and patient, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to me all return in their seasons. There are brightnesses in my secret
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: places in the woods, and lamps in my gardens beneath the hills, tended
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by the angels of God, and behind my face there is another face not hated
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: by the Bright Ones."
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: So the three Absolutes arose and strode mightily away; and as they went
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their thunderous speech to each other boomed against the clouds and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: earth like a gusty wind, and, even when they had disappeared, that great
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: rumble could be heard dying gently away in the moonlit distances.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: The Thin Woman and the children went slowly forward on the rugged,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: sloping way. Far beyond, near the distant summit of the hill there was a
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: light gleaming.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: "Yonder," said the Thin Woman, "is the Brugh of Angus Mac an Og, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: son of the Dagda Mor," and toward this light she assisted the weary
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: children.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: In a little she was in the presence of the god and by him refreshed
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and comforted. She told him all that had happened to her husband and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: implored his assistance. This was readily accorded, for the chief
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: business of the gods is to give protection and assistance to such of
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: their people as require it; but (and this is their limitation) they
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cannot give any help until it is demanded, the freewill of mankind being
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the most jealously guarded and holy principle in life; therefore, the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: interference of the loving gods comes only on an equally loving summons.
title: The Crock of Gold

text: CHAPTER XVIII
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: CAITILIN NI MURRACHU sat alone in the Brugh of Angus much as she had sat
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: on the hillside and in the cave of Pan, and again she was thinking. She
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was happy now. There was nothing more she could desire, for all that the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: earth contained or the mind could describe was hers. Her thoughts were
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: no longer those shy, subterranean gropings which elude the hand and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: understanding. Each thought was a thing or a person, visible in its own
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: radiant personal life, and to be seen or felt, welcomed or repulsed, as
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: was its due. But she had discovered that happiness is not laughter or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: satisfaction, and that no person can be happy for themselves alone. So
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: she had come to understand the terrible sadness of the gods, and why
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Angus wept in secret; for often in the night she had heard him weeping,
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and she knew that his tears were for those others who were unhappy, and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that he could not be comforted while there was a woeful person or
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: an evil deed hiding in the world. Her own happiness also had become
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: infected with this alien misery, until she knew that nothing was alien
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: to her, and that in truth all persons and all things were her brothers
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: and sisters and that they were living and dying in distress; and at
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the last she knew that there was not any man but mankind, nor any human
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: being but only humanity. Never again could the gratification of a desire
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: give her pleasure for her sense of oneness was destroyed--she was not an
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: individual only; she was also part of a mighty organism ordained, through
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: whatever stress, to achieve its oneness, and this great being was
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: threefold, comprising in its mighty units God and Man and Nature--the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: immortal trinity. The duty of life is the sacrifice of self: it is to
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: renounce the little ego that the mighty ego may be freed; and, knowing
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: this, she found at last that she knew Happiness, that divine discontent
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: which cannot rest nor be at ease until its bourne is attained and the
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: knowledge of a man is added to the gaiety of a child. Angus had told her
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: that beyond this there lay the great ecstasy which is Love and God and
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the beginning and the end of all things; for everything must come from
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: the Liberty into the Bondage, that it may return again to the Liberty
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: comprehending all things and fitted for that fiery enjoyment. This
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: cannot be until there are no more fools living, for until the last fool
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: has grown wise wisdom will totter and freedom will still be invisible.
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: Growth is not by years but by multitudes, and until there is a common
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: eye no one person can see God, for the eye of all nature will scarcely
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: be great enough to look upon that majesty. We shall greet Happiness by
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: multitudes, but we can only greet Him by starry systems and a universal
title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James

text: love.
title: The Crock of Gold

text: fluid became locked, and organic with a simultaneous understanding, a

title: The Crock of Gold

title: The Crock of Gold
author: Stephens, James
